questions.text: Northern blotting is used for detection of which of the following? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) RNA

 

Northern blotting is a laboratory technique used to detect specific RNA sequences within a sample. This method involves the separation of RNA by gel electrophoresis, transfer to a membrane, and hybridization with a labeled complementary DNA probe. The technique allows for the identification and analysis of RNA molecules, making it a valuable tool in gene expression studies and diagnostic applications. The name "Northern blotting" was coined as a play on words, referencing the "Southern blot," a technique used for DNA detection developed by Edward M. Southern.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. DNA: This is detected by Southern blotting, not Northern blotting. Southern blotting involves the identification of specific DNA sequences using DNA probes.

 

Option C. Proteins: This is detected by Western blotting. Western blotting uses antibodies to identify specific protein sequences after separation by SDS-PAGE.

 

Educational Objective

 

SNoW - DRoP:-

 

  1. SOUTHERN - DNA
  2. NORTHERN - RNA
  3. WESTERN - Protein

choices.text: 1 – Retinal Pigment Epithelium, 2 – Outer Nuclear Layer, 3 – Inner Plexiform Layer, 4 – Ganglion Cell Layer
1 – Outer Nuclear Layer, 2 – Retinal Pigment Epithelium, 3 – Ganglion Cell Layer, 4 – Inner Plexiform Layer
1 – Ganglion Cell Layer, 2 – Inner Plexiform Layer, 3 – Retinal Pigment Epithelium, 4 – Outer Nuclear Layer
1 – Retinal Pigment Epithelium, 2 – Inner Plexiform Layer, 3 – Outer Nuclear Layer, 4 – Ganglion Cell Layer

questions.text: Arrange the following layers of the retina in the correct order from the outermost to the innermost layer. (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1 – Retinal Pigment Epithelium, 2 – Outer Nuclear Layer, 3 – Inner Plexiform Layer, 4 – Ganglion Cell Layer

 

Explanation:


The correct sequence of retinal layers from outermost to innermost is RPE, outer nuclear layer, inner plexiform layer, and ganglion cell layer. The RPE is the outermost layer of the retina, followed by the outer nuclear layer which contains photoreceptor cell bodies. The inner plexiform layer contains synapses between bipolar, amacrine, and ganglion cells, while the ganglion cell layer, containing ganglion cell bodies, is closest to the vitreous.

 

Educational Objective: 


Anatomical sequence of retinal layers from outermost to innermost: 

 

Retinal Pigment Epithelium → Outer Nuclear Layer → Inner Plexiform Layer → Ganglion Cell Layer.

questions.text: The following table gives BP values before and after administration of drug 'X'. What would be the probable mechanism of action of drug 'X'? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. β1 agonist and β2 agonist

 

The drug's likely mechanism of action is β1 and β2 agonism.

 

Due to its action on β1 receptors, there is an increase in the HR of the patient and also of the SBP (Increase in HR leads to an increase in the CO upto a certain extent). The agonistic action on the β2 receptors causes vasodilation and leads to a fall in the DBP.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. α1 agonist and β1 agonist: α1 agonists typically cause vasoconstriction, which would increase both SBP and DBP. This does not align with the observed decrease in DBP.

 

Option B. M2 agonist and M3 agonist: M2 and M3 receptor agonism would likely lead to bradycardia and increased gastrointestinal motility, respectively. They do not explain the observed increase in HR and SBP, nor the decrease in DBP.

 

Option C. α1 antagonist and β2 agonist: While α1 antagonism could contribute to a decrease in DBP through vasodilation, it would not typically cause an increase in SBP and HR, which are more specifically associated with β1 agonism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The combination of increased systolic blood pressure, decreased diastolic blood pressure, and increased heart rate suggests that drug 'X' acts as a β1 and β2 agonist, leading to increased cardiac output and vasodilation.

questions.text: Match the condition with the appropriate diagnostic test: (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A 1, B 2, C 3, D 4

 

  1. Hirschsprung's disease is diagnosed by rectal biopsy, which is the gold standard diagnostic test for this condition.
  2. Posterior urethral valve is diagnosed by micturating cystourethrogram, which is a radiographic imaging test of the bladder and urethra during voiding.
  3. Choledochal cyst is diagnosed by MRCP, which is a non-invasive imaging test that uses magnetic resonance imaging to visualize the biliary tree.
  4. Intussusception is diagnosed by CT scan, which is a diagnostic imaging test that provides detailed images of the abdominal organs and structures.

 

Explanation:

 

A. Hirschsprung's disease: This is a congenital disorder in which nerve cells (ganglion cells) are absent from a segment of the bowel, usually the rectum or sigmoid colon, leading to a functional obstruction. Infants with Hirschsprung's typically have difficulty with bowel movements within the first days of life. The symptoms can include constipation, abdominal distension, and vomiting. It is diagnosed often in the neonatal period with a barium enema and confirmed with suction rectal biopsy showing the absence of ganglion cells.

 

B. Posterior urethral valve (PUV): PUV is a congenital malformation in male child where an abnormality of the posterior urethra prevents urine outflow. This can lead to urinary obstruction, distension of the bladder, and can subsequently cause damage to the kidneys. Common symptoms include weak urine stream, difficulty in urination, recurrent urinary tract infections, and failure to thrive. Diagnosis is usually made with a voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG).

 

C. Choledochal cyst: This is a congenital dilation of the bile ducts, often causing obstruction. Patients may present with the classic triad of abdominal pain, jaundice, and an abdominal mass, although not all these signs may be evident. Over time, choledochal cysts can lead to complications like cholangitis, pancreatitis, or even malignancy. Diagnosis is typically done with imaging like ultrasound or MRCP, and definitive treatment is surgical removal.

 

D. Intussusception: This is a medical condition in which a part of the intestine telescopes into another section, leading to bowel obstruction. It is the most common cause of bowel obstruction in children between the ages of 6 months and 3 years. Symptoms include sudden, severe abdominal pain, vomiting, and "currant jelly" stools (due to mucus and blood). The diagnosis can often be made with an ultrasound or CT abdomen showing the characteristic "target sign" and is typically treated with high pressure enema, although some cases may require surgical intervention.

questions.text: A primigravida is in labour. Her per-vaginal examination revealed a posterior cervix with 5 cm cervical length, 1 cm dilatation, soft consistency, and head at -1 station. Calculate the modified Bishop score? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 5

 

Explanation:

 

Bishop Score

 

  • This is a scoring system used to assess the favorability of the cervix to respond to induction of labor. 
  • A cervix that is soft in consistency, a little dilated, short in length, anteriorly placed and the station of the presenting low down will respond well to induction of labor. 
  • The Bishop score was replaced by the Modified Bishop score, wherein, the cervical effacement (in terms of percentage) was replaced by cervical length (in cm). 
  • The 5 components of the Modified Bishop score are:
    1. Cervical Dilatation
    2. Cervical length
    3. Cervical consistency
    4. Cervical Position
    5. Station of the presenting part

 

Easy to remember Mnemonic

 

B – Bishop

 

I – Effacement

 

S – Station of presenting part

 

H – Hard/ soft (consistency)

 

O – Os dilatation (cervical dilatation)

 

P – Position of the cervix

 

  • The scoring is as shown in the table.
  • Each component is scored from 0 to 3
  • The highest score is 13 and the lowest is 0
  • A favourable score is > 6. This means the patient will respond favorably to methods of induction of labor. 

 

 

Educational Objective:


The Modified Bishop score is used to assess the cervix's favorability for induction, and a score of 5 in this context would be based on specific factors.

 

Ref: Page no 600, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

choices.text: Total lack of natural killer cells
Decrease in lgG and increase in lgM
Inability of neutrophils to fight against infections

questions.text: Which of the subsequent statements accurately describes the immunological anomaly associated with the absence of CD40 in B cells? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Decrease in lgG and increase in lgM

 

The absence of CD40 and its deficiency in B cells results in Hyper IgM syndrome. This condition is characterized by a reduction in IgG levels and an elevation in IgM levels.

 

HYPER IGM SYNDROME

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Total lack of natural killer cells: This is not associated with CD40 deficiency but rather with other immune disorders like severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID).

 

Option B. Lack of CD8 mediated cytotoxicity: CD40/CD40L interactions do not directly affect CD8 T cells. CD8 mediated cytotoxicity is more related to T cell receptor function and MHC class I interactions.

 

Option D. Inability of neutrophils to fight against infections: While CD40 deficiency can lead to an increased susceptibility to infections, neutrophil function is not directly impaired by the absence of CD40. This function is more related to chronic granulomatous disease or other neutrophil defects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hyper IgM syndrome is characterized by an increased level of IgM and decreased levels of other immunoglobulins like IgG, due to a defect in the CD40/CD40L interaction necessary for immunoglobulin class switching.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presented with a positive Trendelenburg test. Identify the nerve injured: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Superior gluteal nerve

 

  • Function: It innervates the gluteus medius, gluteus minimus, and tensor fasciae latae. These muscles are significant abductors of the hip and play a critical role in pelvis stabilization during walking.
  • Clinical Significance: If this nerve were injured and the patient stood on the left leg, the right side of the pelvis would drop due to the inability to stabilize the pelvis on the stance leg. However, if the Trendelenburg test was positive on the right side, it wouldn't correlate with the left superior gluteal nerve injury.
  • A positive Trendelenburg test indicates a superior gluteal nerve injury.

 

The superior gluteal nerve arises from the sacral plexus and is composed of fibers from L4, L5, and S1 spinal nerves. It innervates the gluteus medius, gluteus minimus, and tensor fasciae latae muscles. The nerve exits the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen above the piriformis muscle and then courses over the surface of the gluteus medius muscle. A lesion to the superior gluteal nerve can result in weakness or paralysis of the gluteus medius and minimus muscles, leading to a Trendelenburg gait.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inferior Gluteal Nerve:

 

  • Function: This nerve primarily innervates the gluteus maximus muscle. The gluteus maximus is the primary extensor of the hip and plays a role in the lateral stabilization of the hip.
  • Clinical Significance: Injury to the inferior gluteal nerve would weaken hip extension but would not directly result in a positive Trendelenburg test.

 

Option C. Sciatic Nerve:

 

  • Function: The sciatic nerve is the largest nerve in the body and originates from the lower spine. It primarily innervates the muscles of the thigh, leg, and foot. It has two major branches, the tibial nerve and the common fibular (peroneal) nerve, which provide motor and sensory function to the lower limb.
  • Clinical Significance: Sciatic nerve compression or irritation can result in a condition known as sciatica. Sciatica is characterized by pain, numbness, tingling, or weakness in the lower back, buttock, and down the back of the leg. Common causes include herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or muscle spasms.

 

Option D. Femoral Nerve:

 

  • Function: The femoral nerve is a branch of the lumbar plexus and provides motor and sensory innervation to the muscles of the thigh and hip joint. It plays a crucial role in thigh flexion and sensation in the anterior thigh and part of the leg.
  • Clinical Significance: Damage or compression of the femoral nerve can lead to symptoms like weakness in thigh muscles, difficulty walking, and sensory deficits in the anterior thigh. Rehabilitation and physical therapy are often used to address femoral nerve issues.

 

Both nerves are vital for the proper function of the lower limbs, and any disturbances or injuries to these nerves can have significant clinical implications, often requiring medical intervention and rehabilitation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The superior gluteal nerve's role in stabilizing the pelvis during gait is critical. A positive Trendelenburg test indicates an inability to maintain pelvic stability due to weakness or paralysis of the gluteus medius and minimus muscles, typically stemming from an injury to the superior gluteal nerve. This understanding is essential for diagnosing and managing conditions related to hip stability and gait abnormalities.

questions.text: Treatment of choice for acute arsenic poisoning is? (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Dimercaprol

 

Dimercaprol is a traditional chelating agent of choice for acute arsenic poisoning. Though now DMSA and DMPS are considered better, as they can be given orally and have lower toxicity. Amongst the given choices, dimercaprol is best answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ipecac: Ipecac is rapidly acting anti-emetic. Earlier it was sometimes used to remove different types of unabsorbed poisons in GIT, but now it is no longer recommended due to limited benefits

 

Option B. Penicillamine: Though it can be used in arsenic, but not a preferred agent. It is preferred chelator for copper.

 

Option C. Activated charcoal: Not useful as it does not adsorb arsenic and other heavy metals

 

Educational Objective:

 

Treatment of Acute Arsenic poisoning

 

  • Hemodynamic stabilization for significant GI losses (vomiting and diarrhea)
  • Gastric lavage is done repeatedly with large amount of warm water and milk;
  • Chelating Agents
    • Chelating agents are useful in acute arsenic poisoning, but have very limited role in chronic arsenic poisoning
    • There are three chelating agents useful in acute arsenic poisoning:
      1. British Anti Lewisite (BAL, aka dimercaprol, dimercaptopropanol): available in IM route. Traditionally BAL was used most commonly for As, but now DMSA and DMPS are considered better, as they can be given orally and have lower toxicity.
      2. Dimercaptosuccinic acid (DMSA, aka succimer): available Orally
      3. Dimercaptopropanesulfonic acid (DMPS, aka Dimerval): available Oral, IM and IV. DMPS is agent of choice for acute As poisoning.

questions.text: First deformity corrected in CTEV is:(INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Cavus

 

CLUB FOOT/CONGENITAL TALIPES EQUINO VARUS (CTEV)

 

  • Incidence: 1:1000 live births
  • M:F – 2.5:1
  • 50% are bilateral
  • In its most characteristic form, there are four elements of deformity – Equinus of ankle, inversion of foot, adduction of fore foot and medial rotation of tibia.

 

 

  • Conservative Management:

 

 

  • First cast in CTEV is applied in supination to correct cavus.
  • Subsequently in kites, one deformity is corrected at a time, adduction first then varus and then equinus (CAVE).
  • In ponsetti method, adduction and Varus are corrected simultaneously and Equinus is corrected at last.
  • Thus in Kites method, one deformity is corrected at a time but in ponsetti adduction and varus are corrected simultaneously, equinus is corrected at end in both.

 

 

Sequential correction

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Forefoot adduction. This is corrected after the correction of the cavus deformity of the foot. (CAVE)

 

Option C. Varus. This is corrected after the correction of cavus followed by forefoot adduction. (CAVE)

 

Option D. Equinus. This is corrected in the last because it is the most resistant deformity. (CAVE)

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis based on the given serum electrophoresis image (pink)? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Nephrotic syndrome

 

The given electrophoresis picture shows hypoalbuminemia and increased alpha-2 globulin, which is suggestive of nephrotic syndrome.

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Multiple myeloma: Multiple myeloma would typically present with a sharp, monoclonal spike in the gamma region (known as an M-spike or paraprotein spike) due to the overproduction of a single type of immunoglobulin by malignant plasma cells. This pattern is not seen in the provided electrophoresis image.

 

Option B. Tuberculosis: Tuberculosis is generally associated with a chronic inflammatory response and can show a polyclonal increase in the gamma region due to chronic immune activation. However, it does not show the specific hypoalbuminemia and alpha-2 globulin increase seen in nephrotic syndrome.

 

Option C. Hepatic cirrhosis: In hepatic cirrhosis, the electrophoresis pattern often shows a polyclonal increase in the gamma region (polyclonal gammopathy), sometimes with a beta-gamma bridging pattern. This pattern is not consistent with the hypoalbuminemia and alpha-2 globulin increase observed in nephrotic syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The electrophoresis pattern showing hypoalbuminemia combined with an increase in alpha-2 globulin is most indicative of nephrotic syndrome, reflecting the characteristic loss of albumin and retention of larger plasma proteins in this condition.

choices.text: Ileocolic, right colic and branch of middle colic
Ileocolic, right colic, stem of middle colic, left colic
Ileocolic, right colic and trunk of middle colic

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient has been diagnosed with proximal transverse colon carcinoma. The physician recommends an extended right colectomy as a treatment option. Which arteries should be resected during an extended right colectomy to prevent the spread of cancer in proximal transverse colon carcinoma? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ileocolic, right colic and trunk of middle colic.

 

During an extended right colectomy, the ileocolic, right colic, and trunk of the middle colic vessels are typically resected to prevent the spread of cancer in proximal transverse colon carcinoma.

 

The stem of the middle colic and the left colic artery are not resected during an extended right colectomy as they are not directly involved with the blood supply to the proximal transverse colon. It is important to note that the surgical management of colon cancer depends on the stage and location of the tumor and may involve various surgical techniques, including colectomy and lymphadenectomy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Types of radical colectomies and vessels ligated:

 

  1. Right hemicolectomy: Ileocolic, right colic and right branch of middle colic artery
  2. Extended right hemicolectomy: Ileocolic, right colic and stem/origin of middle colic artery
  3. Left hemicolectomy: Left colic and sigmoid artery

choices.text: Muscle fasciculations

questions.text: A man was brought to the emergency room after poisoning with an unknown substance. Muscarinic poisoning was suspected and he was treated for the same. What is the possible presenting feature which led to the diagnosis?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Bradycardia
 

The types of Muscarinic receptors and their actions are as follows:

 

  • M1 – They increase the acid secretion in the stomach
  • M2 – They are present in the heart and lead to a decrease in heart rate (Bradycardia) and cause slowing of conduction in the AV node.
  • M3 – They are present in the respiratory tract and cause bronchoconstriction. They are also present in the urinary bladder, where they help in urination by bringing about contraction of the bladder. In the glands, these receptors help in secretion. In the eyes it leads to miosis.

 

Bradycardia is the possible presenting feature which led to the diagnosis of muscarinic poisoning in this case. Muscarinic poisoning occurs due to the consumption of poisonous mushroom-like Inocybe. Muscarinic symptoms appear within an hour of eating the mushroom. These symptoms (along with nicotinic symptoms) can also be seen in organophosphate poisoning. Atropine is used for the management of muscarinic poisoning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mydriasis: This refers to pupil dilation, which is typically associated with sympathetic stimulation or anticholinergic effects, not muscarinic poisoning.

 

Option B. Diuresis: This refers to increased urine production, which is not a direct effect of muscarinic poisoning. Muscarinic activation actually increases bladder contraction, promoting urination.

 

Option C. Muscle fasciculations: These are more associated with nicotinic receptor activation, not muscarinic receptor activation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bradycardia is a key presenting feature that can lead to the diagnosis of muscarinic poisoning. Muscarinic receptors, particularly M2 receptors in the heart, mediate a decrease in heart rate. Atropine is used to manage muscarinic poisoning by blocking acetylcholine's action on these receptors.

questions.text: Which of the following is the least likely condition to exhibit lesions and changes on the anterior shin? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hypothyroidism

 

Hypothyroidism is the least likely among the given conditions to present with specific skin lesions or changes on the anterior shin. Hypothyroidism can lead to generalized skin changes like dryness and edema (notably myxedema), but it is not typically associated with localized lesions on the shin.

 

Myxedema (severe hypothyroidism) is unlikely to present with lesions over shin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sarcoidosis: In Lofgren syndrome which is acute form of sarcoidosis, Erythema nodosum Skin lesions can be seen on shin as seen in the image below.

 

 

Option B. Diabetes: Necrobiosis lipoidica Diabeticorum classically seen on anterior surface of legs.

 

 

Necrobiosis lipoidica Diabeticorum

 

Option C. Hyperthyroidism: Pretibial myxoedema is the infiltrative dermopathy (mucin deposition) seen over shin and it can be seen in Grave's disease which is a type of hyperthyroidism.

 

Pretibial myxoedema is depicted in below image:

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with ascites and undergoes paracentesis. His serum ascites albumin gradient (SAAG) is ≥1.1 g/dL. Which of the following is least likely to be the cause of his ascites?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tuberculous peritonitis

 

The serum ascites albumin gradient (SAAG) helps differentiate ascites caused by portal hypertension from non-portal hypertensive causes. A SAAG ≥1.1 g/dL is indicative of ascites due to portal hypertension, which is commonly seen in conditions such as cirrhosis, liver failure, and metastasis to the liver.

 

In contrast, tuberculous (TB) peritonitis is associated with a SAAG <1.1 g/dL, as it is not related to portal hypertension. TB peritonitis often presents with ascitic fluid lymphocytosis and an elevated ascitic adenosine deaminase (ADA) level, which is highly sensitive for the condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cirrhosis: Cirrhosis is a common cause of portal hypertension, leading to a high SAAG (≥1.1 g/dL).

 

Option B. Liver failure: Liver failure can also result in portal hypertension and ascites with a high SAAG.

 

Option C. Metastasis to the liver: Metastasis to the liver can cause portal hypertension, resulting in a high SAAG.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A SAAG ≥1.1 g/dL indicates ascites due to portal hypertension, commonly seen in conditions like cirrhosis, liver metastasis, and cardiac ascites.
  • A SAAG <1.1 g/dL is seen in conditions unrelated to portal hypertension, such as tuberculous peritonitis, peritoneal carcinomatosis, or pancreatic ascites.

questions.text: Finasteride is used to treat male-pattern baldness by inhibiting which of the following enzymes?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 5-alpha reductase

 

Finasteride is used to treat male pattern baldness by inhibiting 5-alpha reductase.

 

Finasteride is a competitive inhibitor of the 5-alpha-reductase enzyme, which inhibits the conversion of testosterone into its more active form, dihydrotestosterone (DHT). DHT is a key factor in the development of male pattern baldness. By inhibiting type 2 5-alpha reductase, finasteride reduces the amount of DHT in the scalp, slowing hair loss and, in some cases, promoting hair regrowth. It is also used to treat benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) by reducing prostatic epithelial cell proliferation.

 

Important Points:

 

  • The therapeutic effects are usually noticeable after about 6 months of treatment.
  • New hair growth is lost once the treatment is discontinued, similar to minoxidil.
  • Adverse effects include decreased libido, erectile dysfunction, and ejaculation disorders.

 

Finasteride is teratogenic, meaning it can cause abnormalities in male fetuses. Pregnant women should not be exposed to finasteride due to the risk of genital malformations in male babies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aromatase: Aromatase is an enzyme that converts androgens into estrogens. Inhibition of aromatase is used in the treatment of estrogen-dependent breast cancers, not for male-pattern baldness.

 

Option B. 17-hydrolase: 17-hydrolase is involved in steroidogenesis, particularly in the production of cortisol and sex steroids. Inhibition of 17-hydrolase is not related to hair loss treatment.

 

Option D. Phosphodiesterase: Phosphodiesterase inhibitors are used in the treatment of erectile dysfunction (such as sildenafil) by increasing cyclic GMP levels, leading to smooth muscle relaxation in the penis. It is not involved in the treatment of male-pattern baldness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Finasteride works by inhibiting 5-alpha reductase, which blocks the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone (DHT), a major factor in male-pattern baldness and benign prostatic hyperplasia.

Oocysts are immediately infective after being excreted in stool
It is an obligate intracellular organism

questions.text: A patient who underwent a renal transplant 3 months ago comes with complaints of diarrhea for the last 9 days. The stool sample was subject to Kinyoun stain revealing 4-6m structures shown below. Which of the following is true about the organism? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Oocysts are immediately infective after being excreted in stool

 

Oocysts are immediately infective after being excreted in the stool.

 

Causative organism - Cryptosporidium hominis (more common), C.parvum

 

Causes intractable diarrhoea in immunocompromised patients.

 

Infective form - oocyst.

 

The oocyst is spherical or oval and measures about 5 μm in diameter. Oocyst does not stain with iodine and is acid-fast. The wall of the oocysts is thick, but in 20% cases, wall may be thin. These thin-walled oocysts are responsible for autoinfection.

 

Diagnosis is made by demonstration of the oocysts in feces.

 

  • A direct wet mount reveals colorless, spherical oocyst of 4-5 μm, containing large and small granules.
  • The oocysts are difficult to visualize in unstained wet preparations. Modified ZN staining is the method of choice and by this method oocysts appear as red acid-fast spheres, against a blue background.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pathogen does not show autoinfection: This is incorrect. Cryptosporidium can indeed cause autoinfection. Thin-walled oocysts are responsible for autoinfection, perpetuating the infection within the host.

 

Option B. Cryptosporidium parvum is the most common organism implicated worldwide: While Cryptosporidium parvum is a common cause, Cryptosporidium hominis is more frequently implicated in human infections worldwide.

 

Option D. It is an obligate intracellular organism: Cryptosporidium is not strictly obligate intracellular; it can survive outside the host as an oocyst.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cryptosporidium oocysts are immediately infective after being excreted in the stool, and the infection can cause severe diarrhea, particularly in immunocompromised individuals. The oocysts are identifiable by their acid-fast property in modified Ziehl-Neelsen stains.

 

Comparative features of coccidian parasites:

questions.text: M3 incisional hernia refers to: (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Umbilical

 

According to the European Hernia Society classification, M3 incisional hernia refers to umbilical hernia.

 

M=Midline, L=Lateral

 

M1: defect up to 3 cm below xiphoid

 

M3: Defect within 3 cm of umbilicus (above or below)

 

M5: Defect up to 3 cm above pubis

 

M2: Defects between M1 and M3

 

M4: Defects between M3 and M5.

questions.text: The test given below in the image is used for: (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Stereopsis test

 

The test shown in the above image is Titmus stereotest, which is done to test for stereopsis (perception of depth).

 

  • Patients are shown a picture of a housefly for children and circular patterns for adults.
  • The picture is held about 16 inches in front of the patient's eyes.
  • Patients are asked to wear polarized glasses during the test.
  • Normal perception of depth will cause the housefly to appear as a 3D image above the plane.
  • Patients will attempt to pinch the wings of the housefly in the air, above the plane of the image, if perception of depth is normal.
  • Defective perception of depth will cause the image to appear as a normal 2D image.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ocular deviation: This refers to misalignment of the eyes, typically tested with cover tests or Hirschberg test, not the Titmus stereotest.

 

Option C. Refractive errors: These are assessed with vision tests using an eye chart, not stereopsis tests.

 

Option D. Colour Blindness: This is assessed using color vision tests like the Ishihara test, not related to depth perception tests like the Titmus stereotest.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Titmus stereotest evaluates stereopsis or depth perception, an essential aspect of binocular vision, allowing for the three-dimensional interpretation of the world necessary for various activities and indicating healthy, cooperative eye function.

questions.text: Which of the following pairs is incorrectly matched? [INICET MAY 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Diagnostic Study - CONSORT

 

  • The reporting standards employed for presenting the outcomes of Randomized Controlled Trials (RCTs) are known as CONSORT, which stands for Consolidated Standards of Reporting Trials.
  • CONSORT (Consolidated Standards of Reporting Trials) is intended for reporting the outcomes of randomized controlled trials (RCTs), not diagnostic studies.
  • The correct reporting guidelines for diagnostic studies are STARD (Standards for Reporting of Diagnostic Accuracy).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Observational study – MOOSE: MOOSE is Meta-analyses Of Observational Studies in Epidemiology

 

Option B. Systematic review – PRISMA: The Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA) statement (2009) helps systematic reviewers transparently report why the review was done, what the authors did, and what they found.

 

Option D. Case report – CARE: The CARE guidelines (for CAse REports) were developed by an international group of experts to support an increase in the accuracy, transparency, and usefulness of case reports.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Note - More reporting guidelines can be found on Equator network

questions.text: Identify the refractive error: (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Myopia

 

As a result of parallel rays being focused in front of the retina in the image above, myopia is indicated as the refractive error.

 

Myopia, also referred to as "short sight," is a dioptric condition of the eye in which incident parallel rays focus anterior to the light-sensitive layer of the retina while accommodation is at rest.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Presbyopia: It is an age-related condition characterized by a gradual loss of the eyes' ability to focus on nearby objects, due to the hardening of the lens inside the eye.

 

Option C. Hypermetropia: Also known as farsightedness, in this condition, light rays entering the eye focus behind the retina. Individuals with hypermetropia see distant objects more clearly than close ones.

 

 

 

Option D. Astigmatism: This refractive error occurs due to an irregular curvature of the cornea or lens, which causes light to be focused at multiple points in front of, on, or behind the retina, leading to blurred or distorted vision at all distances.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myopia results from the focusing of light in front of the retina, making distant objects appear blurry, a condition often corrected with concave lenses.

questions.text: 60-year-old lady presented with chest pain and exertional dyspnea. Her family says she was previously healthy and there was no similar disease in the family members. ECG on arrival is suggestive of Anterior wall MI. Her son succumbed to Severe COVID-19 pneumonia. CAG showed normal epicardial coronaries. What is the likely diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Takotsubo cardiomyopathy

 

Stress cardiomyopathy commonly affects Women (post-menopausal) > men predominantly due to emotional > physical stress.

 

Neurogenic myocardial stunning occurs leading to heart failure. Beta2 (Gs stimulation) at base and Beta2 (Gi) activation leads to hypercontractility at the base & apical ballooning giving a typical Takotsubo appearance.

 

ECG mimic ACS, RWMA not corresponding to single artery territory, normal CAG with Mild troponin elevation are clues to takotsubo.

Treatment with beta-blockers, ACE inhibitors if non-responsive. Carries good prognosis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. No signs of infection/Inflammation are given in the history. In presence of stress and temporal association, infection less likely.

 

Option C. Normal CAG rules out significant macrovascular CAD.

 

Option D. HCM shows dagger like q waves, SAM, Asymmetrical septal hypertrophy on ECHO.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Takotsubo cardiomyopathy can present with symptoms and ECG changes similar to those of an acute myocardial infarction, but it is distinguished by normal coronary arteries on angiography and is often precipitated by severe emotional stress, fitting the patient's recent personal history.

 

Reference - Harrison/Cardiology/Cardiomyopathies/Chap 259.

questions.text: Which of the following is involved in recognition and clearance of necrotic cells? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inflammasome

 

Inflammasomes are involved in the recognition and clearance of necrotic cells.

 

Inflammasomes are large cytosolic multiprotein complexes that assemble in response to detection of infection- or stress-associated stimuli and lead to the activation of caspase-1-mediated inflammatory responses, including cleavage and unconventional secretion of the leaderless proinflammatory cytokines IL-1β and IL-18, and initiation of an inflammatory form of cell death referred to as pyroptosis.

 

Inflammasomes are involved in pyroptosis, a process of programmed cell death distinct from apoptosis and necrosis. This process is dependent on caspases 1, 4, and 5 and is responsible for killing of infected cells. It occurs in the following sequence:

 

  • Activation of inflammasome complex by infected cells
  • This causes activation of caspase-1
  • This results in generation of IL-1, which is responsible for fever, inflammation, leukocyte recruitment.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Toll-like receptors (TLRs): Toll-like receptors are pattern recognition receptors that detect pathogen-associated molecular patterns (PAMPs) and play a significant role in initiating the innate immune response. However, they are not directly involved in the recognition or clearance of necrotic cells.

 

Option C. P selectin: P selectin is a cell adhesion molecule found on the surface of activated endothelial cells and platelets. It mediates the initial interactions between leukocytes and endothelial cells during inflammation, but it is not involved in the recognition or clearance of necrotic cells.

 

Option D. Manoreceptor: This appears to be a typographical error, possibly meant to refer to the mannose receptor. The mannose receptor is involved in recognizing microbial sugars and is part of the immune system's response to pathogens. However, it is not involved in the clearance of necrotic cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inflammasomes are crucial in the recognition and clearance of necrotic cells by activating caspase-1 and inducing the secretion of pro-inflammatory cytokines, as well as triggering pyroptosis, an inflammatory form of cell death.

questions.text:
What are the recommended actions according to Neonatal Resuscitation guidelines for a baby born with meconium-stained amniotic fluid? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. lntrapartum suction of nose and mouth before delivery of shoulder
  2. lntratracheal suction in case of non-vigorous baby
  3. Gentle suction of nose and mouth in case of vigorous baby
  4. PPV in case of non-vigorous baby after early steps
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 4


According to the Neonatal Resuscitation guidelines, the recommended actions for a newborn with meconium-stained amniotic fluid are as follows:

 

4. For a non-vigorous baby (poor muscle tone, weak or absent respiratory effort, or heart rate <100 bpm): The baby should receive positive pressure ventilation (PPV) following initial resuscitation steps. The current guidelines recommend PPV over routine intratracheal suctioning in non-vigorous infants because studies have shown that routine suctioning does not improve outcomes and may delay necessary resuscitation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1, 2, 3, 4: Intrapartum suction of the nose and mouth before delivery of the shoulders and routine intratracheal suctioning are no longer recommended in the current guidelines.

 

Option B. 2, 4: While PPV is recommended for non-vigorous infants, routine intratracheal suctioning is not indicated.

 

Option D. 1, 3, 4: Intrapartum suction is not recommended under the current guidelines.

 

Educational Objective:
 

For a newborn with meconium-stained amniotic fluid, PPV is administered if the baby is non-vigorous after the initial steps of resuscitation.

questions.text: A patient who receives recurrent transfusions for thalassemia develops fever and chills during this time. There is no evidence of hemolysis. Which of the following measures can decrease the rate of transfusion reactions? (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Leuko-reduced RBCs

 

The given scenario is suggestive of febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction (FNHTR). Such reactions can be prevented by using leuko-reduced RBCs

 

Fever (elevation of temperature by 1º C or 2º F) , chills, or rigors resulting from cytokines released by leukocyte in transfused red cell or platelet components is called as non-hemolytic febrile transfusion reaction. It is a diagnosis of exclusion, as hemolytic and septic reactions can present similarly.

 

Prevention –

 

  1. Pre-storage leukoreduction
  2. Acetaminophen if persistent fever
  3. Routine pretreatment with acetaminophen
  4. Use of platelet additive solution
  5. Plasma reduced or washed products if severe reactions
  6. Restrictive transfusion approach in high-risk patients

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Antibiotics: Antibiotics are not used to prevent transfusion reactions. They are used to treat bacterial infections and would not be effective in preventing FNHTR, which is not caused by bacterial contamination.

 

Option C. Irradiation: Irradiation of blood products is used to prevent transfusion-associated graft-versus-host disease (TA-GvHD), a different type of transfusion reaction, but it does not prevent FNHTR.

 

Option D. Washed RBCs: Washing RBCs removes plasma proteins and is used to prevent allergic reactions in patients with a history of severe allergic transfusion reactions, but it is not specifically aimed at preventing FNHTR. However, washed products can be used if the FNHTR is severe or recurrent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Leuko-reduced RBCs are the preferred method to reduce the risk of febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reactions (FNHTR), especially in patients requiring frequent transfusions like those with thalassemia.

 

  • FNHTRs are commonly due to cytokines released from donor leukocytes or recipient antibodies against donor leukocytes.
  • Leukoreduction removes most white blood cells from the blood product, thereby:
    • Reducing cytokine accumulation
    • Lowering risk of FNHTRs
    • Also helps prevent HLA alloimmunization and CMV transmission

choices.text: Safety in pregnancy
Dose adjustment in renal failure
Cost ratio from cheap to expensive
As per safety or therapeutic index

questions.text: Category A, B, C, D, X in drug classification is indicative of which of the following?(INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Safety in pregnancy

 

The categories A, B, C, D, and X are used to classify drugs based on their safety during pregnancy. This classification helps in determining the potential risk of medications to the fetus when taken during pregnancy.

 

Pregnancy drug category, which are indicative of their safety are as follows:

 

Category A > B > C > D > X

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dose adjustment in renal failure: Drug classifications for dose adjustments in renal failure typically involve guidelines based on the drug's pharmacokinetics and renal clearance. These guidelines are not categorized as A, B, C, D, X.

 

Option C. Cost ratio from cheap to expensive: Drug classifications based on cost are not typically denoted by the categories A, B, C, D, X. Cost-related classifications might be discussed in economic terms or based on generic versus brand name distinctions.

 

Option D. As per safety or therapeutic index: The therapeutic index of a drug, which measures its safety margin, is not categorized using the A, B, C, D, X system. The therapeutic index is a ratio comparing the toxic dose to the therapeutic dose, but it is not classified in this alphabetical manner.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The classification of drugs into categories A, B, C, D, and X is specifically used to indicate their safety during pregnancy, helping healthcare providers to make informed decisions about medication use in pregnant patients.

choices.text: a, b and c are correct

questions.text:
Choose the correct statements regarding the mosquito shown in the image: 

 

 

  1. The mosquito exhibits a hunchback posture when at rest.
  2. This is the only mosquito species that does not have a siphon tube.
  3. It is commonly known as the 'Tiger mosquito.'
  4. It is also referred to as the 'Nuisance mosquito.'
questions.solution:
Ans. C) a and c are correct

 

The mosquito depicted in the image is the Aedes mosquito, which has some distinctive features:

 

Statement a: Correct. The Aedes mosquito displays a hunchback posture when it is at rest, a typical feature that helps identify it.

 

Statement c: Correct. The Aedes mosquito is often referred to as the 'Tiger mosquito' due to the black and white stripes on its legs.

 

Other Options:

 

Statement b: Incorrect. The Aedes mosquito larvae do have a siphon tube. The absence of a siphon tube is a characteristic of Anopheles mosquito larvae.

 

Statement d: Incorrect. The term 'Nuisance mosquito' is not a common designation for the Aedes mosquito. This term can refer broadly to mosquitoes that are bothersome but is not specifically used for Aedes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Aedes mosquito can be identified by its hunchback posture when resting and is commonly known as the 'Tiger mosquito' due to the distinct striping on its legs.

questions.text: Which sequence of dyes is employed for ocular surface examination and dry eye staining? (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Fluorescein → Lisssamine green → Rose Bengal

 

The optimal sequence of dyes for ocular surface examination and dry eye staining from the provided choices is as follows: Fluorescein → Lisssamine green → Rose Bengal

 

Fluorescein stain – it is an orange colored dye → stains the defect. Under cobalt blue light, the defect appears green.

 

Rose Bengal stain – stains the dead cells. It causes stinging, so, not very popular, and so applied the last.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The recommended sequence of application—starting with fluorescein, followed by lissamine green, and ending with Rose Bengal—minimizes discomfort and interference between the dyes. Since Rose Bengal can be irritating, it is applied last, after the assessment with the less irritating dyes has been completed.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis with hypertension? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Liddle syndrome

 

Liddle syndrome is a genetic disorder characterized by the overactivation of the epithelial sodium channels (ENaC) in the principal cells of the kidneys. This overactivation is due to a gain-of-function mutation in the genes encoding these channels. The increased activity of ENaC leads to excessive reabsorption of sodium and water, causing hypertension. Concurrently, there is increased excretion of potassium and hydrogen ions, which results in hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis.

 

This condition is often referred to as pseudo-hyperaldosteronism because it mimics the effects of aldosterone but without elevated aldosterone levels. The treatment of choice for Liddle syndrome is amiloride, which directly inhibits ENaC channels, unlike spironolactone, which is ineffective in this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bartter syndrome: Bartter syndrome also presents with hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis, but patients typically have normal blood pressure. It is a group of autosomal recessive disorders that affect the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle, mimicking the effects of loop diuretics. Symptoms often present in childhood and may include polyuria, polydipsia, and growth delays. Additionally, patients might have nephrocalcinosis due to increase urinary calcium, recurrent urinary stones, and sometimes sensorineural deafness.

 

Option C. Gitelman syndrome: Gitelman syndrome, like Bartter syndrome, involves hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis with normal blood pressure. It affects the distal convoluted tubule of the kidney, similar to the action of thiazide diuretics. Patients usually present in adulthood with symptoms such as muscle weakness, cramps, and tetany due to hypomagnesemia, which is a significant feature distinguishing it from Bartter syndrome.

 

Option D. Gordon syndrome: Gordon syndrome, or pseudohypoaldosteronism type II, is characterized by hypertension and hyperkalemia, along with metabolic acidosis, not alkalosis. It results from mutations leading to increased sodium chloride reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubule. Unlike Liddle syndrome, patients with Gordon syndrome exhibit hyperkalemia and acidosis due to chloride retention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Liddle syndrome is characterized by hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis and hypertension due to the overactivation of epithelial sodium channels in the kidneys.

questions.text: Identify the type of skull fracture sustained in a motorcycle accident? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Hinge fracture

 

Image shows a transverse fracture of the base of the skull that completely splits it and divide it into two halves, each moving independently of each other like a hinge (‘nodding face’ sign).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Depressed fracture of skull: When a portion of fractured bone is driven inwards to a distance equivalent to the thickness of the skull table, it is known as depressed fracture. The picture in the question have a transverse fracture dividing the base of the skull and is not a depressed fracture hence this option is incorrect.

 

Option C) Pond fracture is the other name of pediatric depressed skull fracture. It is primarily due to increased plasticity of the immature skeleton in young children. The picture in the question have a transverse fracture dividing the base of the skull and is not a depressed fracture hence this option is incorrect.

 

Option D) Comminuted fracture of skull: is when two or more intersecting lines of fracture divide the bone into three or more fragments resembling a spider web or mosaic pattern this is not the case in this picture hence this option is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

‘Hinge’ (also called Motorcyclist):

 

  • linear fracture passes across the middle cranial fossa, separating the skull base into Ant and post halves,
  • Occurs Severe Force to side of head (e.g. in motorcycle accidents).
  • Such fractures are commonly associated with injuries of the brain stem, especially pontomedullary tears.

choices.text: High concentration of arsenic from shaft of hair
Cadaveric spasm with mud in closed fist

questions.text: The dead body of a 4-year-old child who was playing around the riverside and accidentally drowned in the river is recovered. There is frothing seen from his mouth and nose. Which of the below postmortem findings is not seen in a case of drowning? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. High concentration of arsenic from shaft of hair

 

The image shows frothing from nostrils which is likely to be due to antemortem drowning.

 

This finding is unrelated to drowning and would suggest chronic arsenic poisoning rather than an acute drowning incident.

 

Postmortem changes of drowning:

 

  • Bloody froth in the airway
  • Water in the stomach and small intestine
  • Water in middle ear
  • Cerebral edema
  • Bloated and cyanosed face
  • Petrous or mastoid hemorrhage.
  • Voluminous / ballooned out lungs
  • Suffused conjunctive, dilated pupils
  • "Washerwoman" changes of the hands (shriveling of the skin) develop when submerged in water for several hours
  • Cadaveric spasm with mud in closed fist 
  • Cutis anserina / goose skin- The contraction of the erector pilorum muscles causes puckering and a grainy appearance of the skin.
  • Cadaveric spasm - Gravel, weed, soil, grass, etc. is firmly held in the clenched hands due to cadaveric spasm. This is a vital sign of antemortem drowning.
  • Rigor mortis - This appears early in cases of a violent antemortem struggle.
  • Diatom test

 

Gettler test can be done to estimate the chloride content in the right and left sides of the heart to differentiate between freshwater and saltwater drowning.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Voluminous and ballooned out lungs: Seen in drowning due to the inhalation of water.

 

Option C. Paltauf's hemorrhage in sub pleura: Hemorrhages found beneath the pleura, associated with drowning.

 

Option D. Cadaveric spasm with mud in closed fist: Indicates a struggle and is a sign of antemortem drowning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of drowning, typical findings include frothing from the mouth and nose, voluminous lungs, and cadaveric spasm with debris. High arsenic concentration in hair shafts is not associated with drowning.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a symptom of severe dehydration? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Thirsty child.

 

Dehydration in children is classified based on clinical signs into mild (some dehydration) and severe dehydration. The symptoms of severe dehydration are crucial for determining the appropriate treatment and urgency of care.

 

"Thirsty child," is typically associated with some dehydration rather than severe dehydration. A thirsty child is likely still alert and responsive, seeking fluids, which suggests that dehydration is present but not yet severe.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Drowsy child: Indicates severe dehydration where the child’s mental status is altered, often due to inadequate perfusion to the brain.

 

Option B. Skin pinch retracts slowly: This is a reliable sign of severe dehydration and indicates significant fluid loss.

 

Option D. Sunken fontanelle: Especially in infants, a sunken fontanelle is a common and concerning sign of severe dehydration, indicating decreased intracranial pressure due to fluid loss.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A thirsty child indicates some dehydration, whereas signs like drowsiness, slow skin pinch retraction, and a sunken fontanelle are indicative of severe dehydration.

questions.text: Neurogenic shock is associated with _______. (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypotension + bradycardia

 

Neurogenic shock is associated with hypotension and bradycardia.

 

This type of shock occurs due to a loss of sympathetic tone in the peripheral vascular system, which leads to vasodilation and decreased vascular resistance. The result is hypotension. In contrast to other types of shock (which often involve compensatory tachycardia), neurogenic shock is unique because of bradycardia, due to the disruption of sympathetic innervation to the heart and unopposed vagal (parasympathetic) activity.

 

Neurogenic shock is most commonly caused by spinal cord injuries, particularly injuries to the cervical or upper thoracic regions, which disrupt the autonomic nervous system's ability to regulate blood pressure and heart rate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypertension + tachycardia: These findings are not typical of neurogenic shock. Hypertension and tachycardia may be seen in other conditions, such as adrenergic crises or hypertensive emergencies.

 

Option B. Hypotension + tachycardia: This is more characteristic of other types of shock, like hypovolemic or septic shock, where compensatory tachycardia is seen as a response to low blood pressure.

 

Option D. Hypertension + bradycardia: While bradycardia can occur in neurogenic shock, hypertension is not typically associated with this condition. Instead, hypotension is the hallmark due to peripheral vasodilation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neurogenic shock is a type of distributive shock associated with hypotension and bradycardia due to the loss of sympathetic tone following spinal cord injuries, leading to vasodilation, decreased cardiac output, and unopposed vagal activity.

choices.text: Vagal output to cardiac fibres increase

questions.text: Which of the following events occur immediately when a person changes his/her posture from supine to standing? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Decrease in firing from baroreceptor

 

When a person changes posture from supine to standing, the immediate effect is a decrease in mean arterial pressure (MAP) due to gravity causing blood to pool in the lower extremities. This results in decreased venous return and cardiac output and decreased firing from the baroreceptors.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vagal output to cardiac fibers increase: Incorrect. The vagal (parasympathetic) output decreases when standing to allow an increase in heart rate and cardiac output.

 

Option C. Mesenteric vasoconstriction: Incorrect. Although mesenteric vasoconstriction occurs due to sympathetic activation, it is not the immediate response; the initial response is the decrease in baroreceptor firing.

 

Option D. Increase cardiac contractility: Incorrect. While increased cardiac contractility occurs due to sympathetic activation, it is a subsequent response following the decrease in baroreceptor firing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The immediate response when a person changes posture from supine to standing is a decrease in baroreceptor firing due to a reduction in mean arterial pressure.

questions.text: To which organism does the provided image of the cell wall belong? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Neisseria meningitides

 

  • The displayed picture illustrates a cell wall of a gram negative bacteria
  • It shows presence of  lipooligosaccharides (LOS), which strongly indicates the presence of Neisseria meningitidis.
  • Unlike lipopolysaccharide (LPS), LOS lacks a lengthy 0-antigen side chain.
  • This unique characteristic makes it a significant virulence factor, observed in only a limited number of organisms, including N. gonorrhoeae, N. meningitidis, H. ducreyi, and others.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Staphylococcus aureus is a gram-positive bacterium and does not have a cell wall structure similar to the one depicted.

 

Option B. Escherichia coli is a gram-negative bacterium, but it has LPS instead of LOS.

 

Option D. Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a gram-negative bacterium, but it has LPS rather than LOS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neisseria meningitidis is identified by the presence of lipooligosaccharides (LOS) in its cell wall, a distinguishing feature of this gram-negative bacterium.

choices.text: Pap smear
Visual inspection with iodine

questions.text: A 62-year-old patient with a history of diabetes and hypertension came with post-menopausal bleeding. Which of the following you will do to evaluate the cause? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Endometrial sampling

 

  • Endometrial sampling is done to evaluate a patient presenting with postmenopausal bleeding.
  • Transvaginal ultrasound (TVS) is a better first-line investigation since TVS is not included in the options, endometrial sampling is the next best answer.
  • Both diabetes and hypertension are risk factors for endometrial hyperplasia and carcinoma hence endometrial sampling would be the more appropriate test as compared to tests for cervical cancer screening.
  • Endometrial sampling is indicated in a woman with post-menopausal bleeding with the endometrial thickness is > 4 mm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pap smear: A pap smear should be done in all women complaining of post menopausal women with a normal looking cervix and a cervical biopsy for all women with a cervical growth but in this question, based on risk factors, we are more worried about endometrial cancer and hence endometrial sampling is a better option.

 

Option B. Visual inspection with iodine: This is not the preferred option and even if cervical cancer screening is warranted, a pap smear or HPV is better.

 

Option C. Colposcopy: This is indicated if there is any cytological abnormality on the pap smear

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endometrial sampling is done to evaluate a patient presenting with postmenopausal bleeding.

 

Ref: Page no 560, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition.

questions.text: Which gene is not involved in double strand DNA break repair mechanism? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) MSH2

 

MSH2 stands for "MutS homolog 2." The gene is located on chromosome 2 and is not directly involved in the repair of double-strand DNA breaks. Instead, MSH2 is a key component of the DNA mismatch repair (MMR) pathway. MMR is responsible for correcting errors that occur during DNA replication, such as mismatches and small insertions or deletions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. BRCA1: BRCA1 (Breast Cancer 1) is involved in the repair of double-strand DNA breaks through the homologous recombination pathway. Mutations in the BRCA1 gene are associated with an increased risk of breast and ovarian cancers.

 

Option C. KU70: KU70, along with KU80, forms the Ku heterodimer (Ku70/Ku80), which is a crucial component of the non-homologous end joining (NHEJ) pathway. NHEJ is a major mechanism for repairing double-strand DNA breaks, especially in the G1 phase of the cell cycle.

 

Option D. ATM: The ATM (ataxia-telangiectasia mutated) gene codes for a protein kinase that plays a central role in the cellular response to double-strand DNA breaks. It activates a signaling cascade that leads to DNA repair and cell cycle control.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 understand the roles of different genes and proteins in the repair of double-strand DNA breaks (DSBs), which is essential for maintaining genome stability and preventing mutations.

questions.text: What is the cause of the lesion shown in the image below?(INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Lightning strike

 

The image shows fern-like patterns, known as Lichtenberg flowers or filigree burns, which are characteristic of lightening injury.

 

Filigree burns:

 

  • Also called Arborescent or Lichtenberger’s flowers
  • They pathognomonic feature of lightening
  • Superficial, thin, irregular and tortuous markings on skin like branches of tree (fern like pattern).
  • They are caused by Slight staining of tissues by hemoglobin from lysed red blood cells (from superficial capillaries) along the path of electric current. Hence, they indicate the path taken by the discharge.
  • They do not follow the path of major blood vessels, but only follow the superficial capillaries
  • Though called Filigree Burns but they are not actually burns
  • They are transient erythema which appears within a few minutes to 1 hour of accident and gradually fades within 24 – 48 hours if the person survives.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Electrocution: Electrocution typically causes electrical burns which are different from the filigree burns seen in lightning strikes. These burns are usually deep and may show entry and exit wounds.

 

Option C. Marbling: Marbling refers to a postmortem change where blood vessels become visible as greenish-black streaks on the skin, occurring due to decomposition and is not related to electrical injuries.

 

Option D. Trickling down of acid: Acid injuries typically cause chemical burns with distinct, often more severe damage to the skin and tissues, and do not produce the characteristic fern-like patterns seen in lightning strikes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Filigree burns or Lichtenberg flowers are pathognomonic for lightning strikes and appear as superficial, fern-like patterns on the skin that fade within 24-48 hours.

questions.text: Which among the following is not used in post laryngectomy rehabilitation?(INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Super supraglottic swallow

 

Super supraglottic swallow is not used in post laryngectomy rehabilitation but in dysphagia to prevent aspiration of food.

 

The Super-Supraglottic Swallow technique is employed for patients experiencing diminished airway closure. To perform this technique, patients are directed to take a deep breath and tightly hold it while bearing down. They should maintain this breath hold and bear down as they swallow. Immediately after the swallow (before inhaling), they are instructed to cough, followed by a forceful swallow once more (before inhaling). This sequence is aimed at enhancing airway protection during swallowing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A tracheoesophageal prosthesis (TEP) is a one-way valve inserted through a tracheoesophageal puncture. Occlusion of the stoma shunts the exhaled air through the TEP into the esophagus producing vibration of the upper esophageal sphincter resulting in phonation.

Option B. Esophageal speech is phonation produced by vibration of the upper esophageal sphincter.

 

Option C. Polite yawning also called nasal airflow-inducing maneuver is indicated for olfaction rehabilitation post laryngectomy. This maneuver induces a negative pressure in the oral cavity and oropharynx, which generates a nasal airflow, enabling odorous substances to reach the olfactory epithelium again.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Super supraglottic swallow technique is crucial for enhancing airway protection in dysphagia management but is not utilized in post-laryngectomy rehabilitation, where the focus is primarily on restoring voice and smell functions through other specialized techniques.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition 352, 353; Scott Brown 7th edition, Volume 2, Page No. 2090

questions.text: Which is not a product of heme catabolism? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Aminolaevulinic acid

 

Heme catabolism is the process by which the heme portion of hemoglobin is broken down. This process begins with the degradation of heme into biliverdin, which is subsequently reduced to bilirubin. This bilirubin is further processed into conjugated bilirubin, urobilinogen, and stercobilinogen. In addition to these products, heme catabolism also generates carbon monoxide and ferrous ion (Fe²⁺).

 

Aminolaevulinic acid, on the other hand, is not a product of heme catabolism but is instead an important precursor in the synthesis of heme. It is formed in the first step of heme synthesis, where succinyl-CoA and glycine combine under the action of the enzyme aminolaevulinic acid synthase.

 

Therefore, while ferrous ion, biliverdin, and carbon monoxide are products of heme catabolism, aminolaevulinic acid is involved in heme synthesis and not in its breakdown.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ferrous ion: This is indeed a product of heme catabolism, as iron is released during the breakdown of the heme group.

 

Option C. Biliverdin: Biliverdin is one of the direct products of heme degradation, and it is subsequently reduced to bilirubin.

 

Option D. Carbon monoxide: This is another product of heme catabolism, and notably, heme catabolism is the only process in the human body where carbon monoxide is produced endogenously.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aminolaevulinic acid is a precursor in the synthesis of heme, not a product of its catabolism.

questions.text: The life cycle of an organism is given below. Identify the vector involved? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Trombiculid mite

 

The above picture shows the life cycle of trombiculid mite.

 

Orientia tsutsugamushi, an obligate intracellular Gram-negative bacterium, is the causative agent of scrub typhus, a vector-borne disease transmitted by infected chiggers (trombiculid mite larvae).

 

Host: A number of small rodents particularly wild rats of subgenus Rattus are the natural hosts for scrub typhus

 

The incubation period of scrub typhus is about 6 to 21 days

 

The infection is transmitted to man and rodents by some species of infective trombiculid mites.

 

Once, the mite is infected in nature by feeding on the body fluid of small mammals, including the rodents, they maintain the infection throughout their life stages and, as adults, pass the infection on to their eggs in a process called transovarial transmission. Similarly, the infection passes from the egg to the larva or adult in a process called transstadial transmission. In this way, chigger mite populations can autonomously maintain their infectivity over long periods of time.

 

A large number of the Orientia tsutsugamushi are present in the salivary glands of the larvae and these are injected into its host when it feeds. The bite of the mite leaves a characteristic black eschar that is useful to the doctor for making the diagnosis.

 

Human infection takes place when man accidentally picks up an infective larval mite while walking, sitting, or lying on the infested ground.

 

The adult mites have a four-stage lifecycle: egg, larva, nymph and adult.

 

The larva is the only stage (chigger) that can transmit the disease to humans and other vertebrates, since the other life stages (nymph and adult) do not feed on vertebrate animals. Both the nymph and the adult are free-living in the soil.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Hard tick: Hard ticks, such as Ixodes species, are vectors for diseases like Lyme disease and are not involved in the life cycle shown in the image.

 

Option B. Soft tick: Soft ticks, like Ornithodoros species, are vectors for diseases such as tick-borne relapsing fever, but are not depicted in the life cycle in the image.

 

Option D. Louse: Lice are vectors for diseases like epidemic typhus, caused by Rickettsia prowazekii, and are not involved in the life cycle shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective

 

The trombiculid mite, particularly its larval stage (chigger), is the vector for scrub typhus, transmitting Orientia tsutsugamushi to humans and rodents through its bite, which leaves a characteristic black eschar.

questions.text: A person who has undergone a bone marrow transplant in the past is now presenting with a lung lesion. Upon microscopic analysis, the image of the lesion is provided below. What is the probable responsible organism for this condition? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Mucormycosis

 

Explanation:

 

Mucormycosis is indicated in this clinical scenario due to the patient's history of a bone marrow transplant and the presence of a lung lesion. The image provided shows broad aseptate hyphae , which is characteristic of Mucormycosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Histoplasma: Is a dimorphic fungus. At 25°C, it shows mycelial phase and at 37°C, it shows Yeast form.

 

 

Option B. Cryptococcus: Colonies can be demonstrated by negative staining of their capsule.

 

 

Option D. Aspergillosis: Shows narrow, acute angled branching and septate, differing from the non-septate hyphae

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mucormycosis  is characterized broad aseptate hyphae with acute -angle branching. which commonly affecting in immunocompromised patients.

questions.text: Type I collagen is not seen in? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Elastic cartilage

 

Elastic cartilage, as the name suggests, is more elastic than other types of cartilage. This is due to the presence of elastic fibers interspersed with the cartilage cells (chondrocytes).

 

The primary collagen in elastic cartilage is Type II collagen, not Type I.

 

Additionally, the elastin present in this cartilage gives it a yellowish appearance and makes it flexible. Examples of elastic cartilage include the external ear (auricle) and the epiglottis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bone: Bone tissue primarily consists of Type I collagen. This collagen provides a framework upon which hydroxyapatite (a crystalline structure made of calcium and phosphate) can deposit, giving bones their characteristic rigidity and strength. Type I collagen provides the bone with some flexibility and tensile strength, which helps to prevent fractures.

 

Option B. Ligament: Ligaments, which connect bone to bone, are primarily composed of Type I collagen. This gives ligaments their tensile strength and ability to withstand pulling forces. The presence of Type I collagen in ligaments helps in maintaining joint stability.

 

Option C. Aponeurosis: An aponeurosis is a flat, sheet-like tendinous structure that attaches muscle to bone or other tissues. Like tendons, aponeuroses primarily contain Type I collagen. This allows aponeuroses to transmit muscular forces effectively.

 

Educational Objective:

 

List of types of collagens in various tissues:

questions.text: A researcher is comparing the means of three different groups with non-normally distributed data and small sample sizes. Which of the following tests is best suited for analyzing this non-parametric data? [INICET NOV 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Friedman test

 

  • Friedman test is a non-parametric statistical test used for detecting differences in treatments across multiple test attempts.
  • It is the equivalent of a one-way ANOVA with repeated measures but for non-parametric data.
  • Since the data in this scenario is not normally distributed, and the groups are related, the Friedman test is the appropriate choice.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Student t-test: Student t-test is used for comparing the means of two groups. However, it assumes that the data is normally distributed. 

 

Option C. ANOVA: ANOVA (Analysis of Variance) is used for comparing the means of three or more independent groups. 

 

Option D. Pearson: Pearson correlation is used for measuring the strength of a linear association between two quantitative variables. It is not a test for comparing means and also assumes a normal distribution of the data.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Choose the Friedman test when you need to compare the means of three or more related groups, and the data is not normally distributed, ensuring accurate and reliable statistical analysis in non-parametric settings.

questions.text: A hypertensive patient who is on losartan develops an HbA1c level of 8.1%. Which of the following drugs would you replace losartan with? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Telmisartan

 

Telmisartan is the appropriate choice for a hypertensive patient with an elevated HbA1c level (8.1%), indicating poorly controlled diabetes. Telmisartan, an angiotensin II receptor blocker (ARB), has unique properties among ARBs due to its partial agonistic activity on peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor-gamma (PPAR-gamma). PPAR-gamma agonists can improve insulin sensitivity and have beneficial effects on glycemic control. This makes Telmisartan particularly useful for patients managing both hypertension and diabetes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amlodipine: Amlodipine is a calcium channel blocker used for hypertension. It does not have the beneficial effects on glycemic control seen with Telmisartan and would not be the preferred choice in a patient with elevated HbA1c.

 

Option C. Metoprolol: Metoprolol is a beta-blocker. While effective for hypertension, beta-blockers can potentially worsen glycemic control and are not ideal for patients with diabetes.

 

Option D. Olmesartan: Olmesartan is another ARB, but unlike Telmisartan, it lacks PPAR-gamma agonistic activity. Thus, it does not offer the additional benefit of improving insulin sensitivity and glycemic control.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For hypertensive patients with diabetes and elevated HbA1c levels, Telmisartan is the preferred replacement for losartan due to its PPAR-gamma agonistic activity, which helps improve glycemic control.

choices.text: A-1, B-2, C-3, D-4
A-4, B-1, C-2, D-3
A-3, B-2, C-1, D-4
A-4, B-3, C-2, D-1

questions.text:
Match the following: (INICET NOV 2024)

 

  1. Marjolin ulcer over the dorsum of the foot measuring 3 x 2 cm
  2. 1.5 cm cervical lymph node in the neck
  3. Soft tissue sarcoma over mid-thigh
  4. Solitary thyroid nodule

 

  1. Excision biopsy
  2. Core needle biopsy
  3. USG guided FNAC
  4. Wedge biopsy
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A-4, B-1, C-2, D-3


The correct answer is Option B. A-4, B-1, C-2, D-3. Here's why:

 

A. Marjolin ulcer over the dorsum of the foot measuring 3 cm x 2 cm – Wedge biopsy: Marjolin's ulcer is a rare and aggressive form of squamous cell carcinoma, which usually arises from a long-standing wound, ulcer, or scar. In this case, a wedge biopsy is the best diagnostic method because it takes a sample of tissue from the edge of the ulcer for histopathological evaluation.

 

B. 1.5 cm cervical lymph node in the neck – Excision biopsy: For lymph node pathology, an excision biopsy is preferred. This method removes the entire lymph node for complete histopathological examination, which is crucial for the diagnosis of malignancies or other pathological conditions.

 

C. Soft tissue sarcoma over mid-thigh – Core needle biopsy: Soft tissue sarcomas are aggressive tumors that require precise diagnosis. A core needle biopsy allows the collection of tissue from the tumor without needing a large excision, thus minimizing risk and providing adequate material for histological analysis.

 

D. Solitary thyroid nodule – USG guided FNAC: Fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) under ultrasound guidance is the investigation of choice for a solitary thyroid nodule. It is a minimally invasive method used to assess whether the nodule is benign or malignant, helping guide further management.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A-1, B-2, C-3, D-4 : This option incorrectly matches the biopsy types. Marjolin's ulcer should be biopsied using a wedge biopsy (not excision), and soft tissue sarcoma requires a core needle biopsy (not FNAC).

 

Option C. A-3, B-2, C-1, D-4: This also mismatches the biopsy types. Marjolin's ulcer should not be evaluated with FNAC, and soft tissue sarcomas are better diagnosed with core needle biopsies rather than excision biopsies.

 

Option D. A-4, B-3, C-2, D-1: The correct combination for a solitary thyroid nodule is USG-guided FNAC, not an excision biopsy.

 

Educational Objective:


Marjolin's ulcer requires a wedge biopsy for diagnosis, soft tissue sarcomas are best diagnosed using core needle biopsy, and USG-guided FNAC is used for thyroid nodules.

questions.text: Which of the following is not usually involved in the immunohistochemistry of acute lymphoblastic leukemia? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cytokeratin

 

Cytokeratin is not a marker of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). It is an epithelial cell marker for thymoma.

 

Immunophenotype in ALL –

 

  • Terminal deoxynucleotidyl-transferase (TdT), a specialized DNA polymerase, is positive in more than 95% of cases.
  • Lymphoblasts usually express the pan B-cell marker CD19 and the transcription factor PAX5, as well as CD10.
  • More mature “late pre-B” ALLs express CD10, CD19, CD20, and cytoplasmic IgM heavy chain (μ chain).
  • T-ALLs are arrested at various stages of pre-T cell development. In most cases the cells are positive for CD1, CD2, CD5, and CD7.
  • “Late” pre-T cell tumors are positive CD3, CD4, and CD8

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. TdT: A highly specific marker for ALL, present in over 95% of cases.

 

Option B. CD1a: Commonly expressed in T-ALL, particularly in early T-cell development stages.

 

Option C. CD3: A marker for T-cell lineage, used in identifying T-ALL and distinguishing it from B-cell lineage ALL.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cytokeratin is not a marker for acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) and is instead an epithelial cell marker used in identifying epithelial tumors such as thymoma.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Pg 111

choices.text: RNA-dependent DNA polymerase inhibition
RNA-dependent RNA polymerase inhibition
Fusion inhibition

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of remdesivir? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. RNA-dependent RNA polymerase inhibition
 

  • Remdesivir is the only FDA approved drug for COVID-19, which is recommended for moderate to severe COVID-19 patients, hospitalized patients, patients on oxygen therapy and should be used within 10 days of disease onset, after which it has no proven benefit.
  • It inhibits RNA-dependent RNA polymerase.
  • While on treatment, monitoring of LFT, KFT and PT are required. It should be avoided in pregnant or lactating females, patients less than 12 years of age, if eGFR <30ml/min or ALT>5 times.
  • Adverse effects include anaphylaxis, nausea and infusion related reactions.

 

Other Options:
