Option A. RNA-dependent DNA polymerase inhibition: This mechanism is not relevant for remdesivir. RNA-dependent DNA polymerase inhibition is associated with drugs targeting retroviruses, like reverse transcriptase inhibitors used in HIV treatment.

 

Option C. Fusion inhibition: Fusion inhibitors prevent the virus from fusing with the host cell membrane, thereby blocking entry into the cell. This is not the mechanism of remdesivir. An example of a fusion inhibitor is enfuvirtide, used in HIV treatment.

 

Option D. Entry inhibition: Entry inhibitors block the virus from entering the host cell. This is also not the mechanism of action for remdesivir. An example of an entry inhibitor is maraviroc, which is used in HIV treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Remdesivir works by inhibiting RNA-dependent RNA polymerase, thus preventing viral RNA replication in COVID-19 patients. It is important to monitor liver and kidney function during treatment and be aware of its contraindications and potential adverse effects.

questions.text: Identify the conduction abnormality from the ECG given below. (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Second degree heart block

 

The ECG shown above is the second-degree atrioventricular block type 1 - Wenckebach phenomenon.

 

Second Degree Heart Block occurs due to the intermittent failure of electrical impulse conduction from the atrium to the ventricle. It is characterized by a missed QRS complex. There are two types:

 

  • Mobitz type 1/Wenckebach: This occurs due to the decremental conduction of electrical impulses in the AV node. The hallmark of this block is the progressive elongation of the PR interval, leading to an eventual drop of the QRS complex. It is commonly seen in young athletes.
  • Mobitz type 2: It occurs in the distal or infra-His conduction system. Unlike Mobitz type 1, the PR interval remains constant, but some P waves fail to conduct, leading to missed QRS complexes. Mobitz type 2 is more serious and may require a pacemaker.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. First degree heart block: This block is characterized by a prolonged but consistent PR interval (greater than 200 milliseconds), with every P wave followed by a QRS complex. There is no dropped QRS in first-degree heart block, unlike the second-degree heart block, which shows intermittent dropped QRS complexes.

 

Option B. Ventricular tachycardia: Ventricular tachycardia appears on the ECG as a wide QRS complex tachycardia with a rate of over 100 beats per minute. This is distinct from the block patterns, which primarily affect the PR interval and conduction between the atria and ventricles.

 

Option C. Third degree heart block: In third-degree (complete) heart block, there is no conduction between the atria and ventricles, leading to independent beating of the atria (P waves) and ventricles (QRS complexes). The PR intervals are variable and unrelated to the QRS complexes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Second-degree heart block type 1 (Wenckebach) is characterized by progressive prolongation of the PR interval until a QRS complex is dropped.

questions.text: According to IADPSG, what is the cut-off value of fasting blood glucose for the diagnosis of gestational diabetes mellitus? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) > 92 mg/dL

 

Explanation:

 

The International Association of Diabetes and Pregnancy Study Groups (IADPSG) has established criteria for the diagnosis of gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM). According to their guidelines:

 

  • The fasting blood glucose cut-off value for diagnosing GDM during a 75g oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT) is >92 mg/dL.

 

This value is used as part of a comprehensive assessment, including 1-hour and 2-hour postprandial glucose levels. The IADPSG criteria for GDM diagnosis include:

 

  • Fasting: ≥92 mg/dL
  • 1-hour: ≥180 mg/dL
  • 2-hour: ≥153 mg/dL

 

If any one of these values is abnormal, the diagnosis of GDM can be made.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. >95 mg/dL: This is not the IADPSG recommended cut-off for fasting blood glucose. It is higher than the specified cut-off value for diagnosing GDM.

 

Option C. >106 mg/dL: This value is significantly higher than the recommended cut-off. It exceeds the threshold for diagnosing GDM according to IADPSG guidelines.

 

Option D. >90 mg/dL: While this value is close, it is slightly below the IADPSG recommended cut-off of >92 mg/dL for diagnosing GDM.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cut-off value of fasting blood glucose for the diagnosis of gestational diabetes mellitus according to IADPSG is >92 mg/dL.

 

Ref: Page no 326, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text: Patellar Clunk Syndrome scar is present at superior pole of patella and impinging on: (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Femoral component during extension

 

PATELLAR CLUNK SYNDROME

 

  • It is knee popping and catching due to fibrous nodule on superior pole of patella in TKR patients that impinges on femoral component on knee extension.
  • If symptoms are severe, it requires resection of fibrous nodule (arthroscopic/open).
  • Patients complain of a clunking during knee extension, caused by a suprapatellar fibrous nodule that interferes with patella movement.
  • There is an accumulation of scar tissue along the undersurface of the quadriceps tendon, proximal to the superior pole of the patella.
  • The cause of scar tissue is unknown, but may be related to:
    • Direct trauma to quadriceps tendon during patella resection during TKR
    • Impingement of the quadriceps tendon on the femoral component due to an undersized patellar component
  • Scar is entrapped within the intercondylar notch during flexion.
  • It impinges on the femoral component and is forced out of the notch during active knee extension.
  • The painful snap or clunk is usually felt between 30-45 degrees
  • Many patients can be managed without surgery.
  • However, if there are persistent symptoms, surgical excision of the nodule can be useful.

 

OTHER SOFT TISSUE DISORDERS

 

  • Irritation of the lateral facet of the patella: Contact between the lateral facet of the patella and the femoral implant, in the region of the lateral condyle, can cause chronic lateral knee pain.
  • Popliteal Tendon Impingement: After TKA, the popliteal tendon can be irritated by overhand of the femoral condyles, from a posterolateral osteophyte, from residual synovium or extruded cement. Patients complain of discrete posterior knee pain that occurs after a specific point of knee flexion.
  • Protruding Medial Tibial Component: Pain along the medial knee can be from the protrusion of the tibial, including medial collateral ligament irritation. Tibial revision is necessary if pain is intolerable.
  • Nerve Injury: Deep peroneal nerve injury is a rare but reported complication of TKA, caused by compression, ischemia, traction, crush, or laceration. It typically occurs when there is surgical correction of a significant preoperative valgus deformity or flexion contracture of the knee. The infrapatellar branch of the saphenous nerve (IBSN) is commonly affected after knee replacement. Patients can report numbness (sometimes a painful numbness) along the lateral aspect of the knee for over a year.
  • Complex Regional Pain Syndrome: Complex Regional Pain Syndrome is a very rare consequence of knee replacement. It is characterized by pain disproportionate to exam findings. There is sensory disturbance (e.g., pain evoked by light brushing of the skin, called allodynia), motor impairment (e.g., weakness), and sympathetic dysfunction (e.g., edema, color changes).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The scar of the patellar clunk syndrome after TKR is present at the superior pole of the patella and it impinges on the femoral component of the implant of active knee extension.

questions.text: All of the following are responsible for Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction except? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) INF- y  

 

Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction (JHR) is associated with a transient, marked rise in circulating tumor necrosis factor alpha (TNF alpha), interleukin 6 (IL-6) and interleukin 8 (IL-8).

 

It is an inflammatory reaction that can occur after treatment for syphilis.

 

The symptoms usually begin 2 hours from the administration of the antibiotic and resolve within 24 hours.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. TNF alpha: Directly involved in the inflammatory response associated with JHR.

 

Option B. IL-6: Also directly involved in JHR, promoting inflammatory processes.

 

Option C. IL-8: Plays a role in recruiting neutrophils to sites of infection, contributing to the inflammatory reaction in JHR.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction is primarily driven by a surge in pro-inflammatory cytokines such as TNF alpha, IL-6, and IL-8, but not by INF-γ.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Incus

 

The image provided is from a mastoidectomy, a procedure where the middle ear structures are often visualized. The incus is one of the three ossicles of the middle ear and is located between the malleus and the stapes. It has a distinctive structure with both a short process and a long process. The long process of the incus articulates with the head of the stapes, facilitating the transmission of sound vibrations from the eardrum to the inner ear. The arrow in the image points to the incus, which confirms the diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Malleus: The malleus is another middle ear ossicle, but it articulates with the tympanic membrane and the incus. The image, however, shows the incus, not the malleus.

 

Option C. Posterior Semicircular Canal: The posterior semicircular canal is part of the inner ear and is involved in balance, but it is not the structure indicated in the image.

 

Option D. Lateral Semicircular Canal: Similar to the posterior semicircular canal, the lateral semicircular canal is also part of the inner ear and plays a role in detecting head rotation, but it is not visible in this image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The incus is one of the three ossicles in the middle ear and plays a crucial role in sound transmission by articulating with the malleus and stapes.

choices.text: Calcium Channel Blocker action
Nitric oxide mediated vasodilation

questions.text: An elderly woman on treatment for migraine presents with chest pain. She has a previous history of ischemic heart disease. Which of the following mechanism of the prescribed drug for migraine might have caused this presentation? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 5-HT agonist

 

Chest pain in an elderly woman with a history of ischemic heart disease, who is on treatment for migraine, could potentially be linked to the mechanism of action of her migraine medication. Among the options given 5-HT agonists can cause this adverse effect. Triptans and ergotamine are a group of drugs that are used in acute attacks of migraine. They act on 5HT1B/1D receptors as agonist and cause vasoconstriction of the blood vessels. Therefore, they should be avoided in patients with coronary artery disease as they can precipitate myocardial infarction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 5-HT Antagonist: Serotonin (5-HT) antagonists like cyproheptadine and methysergide etc are used for prophylaxis of migraine (not in treatment). These drugs are not commonly associated with causing chest pain or exacerbating ischemic heart disease.

 

Option C. Calcium Channel Blocker Action: While calcium channel blockers (CCBs) are used in migraine prophylaxis, they are generally heart-protective and used in the treatment of angina and hypertension due to their vasodilatory effects. It's unlikely that CCBs would cause chest pain.

 

Option D. Nitric Oxide Mediated Vasodilation: Nitric oxide donors (like nitrates) are used in the treatment of angina due to their vasodilatory effects. They are not typically used in migraine treatment, and their vasodilatory action would be more likely to relieve, rather than cause, ischemic chest pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

5-HT Agonist includes medications like triptans (e.g., sumatriptan), which are commonly used in migraine treatment. Triptans are 5-HT1B/1D receptor agonists and can cause vasoconstriction of blood vessels. In patients with ischemic heart disease, this vasoconstriction can exacerbate angina (chest pain) or precipitate myocardial infarction, especially if the coronary arteries are already compromised.

questions.text: t(11,22) is best diagnosed by: (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) FISH

 

t(11,22) can be best detected using fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH). FISH uses DNA probes that recognize sequences specific to particular chromosomal regions. As part of the Human Genome Project, large libraries of bacterial artificial chromosomes that span the entire human genome were created. The human DNA insert in these clones is on the order of 100,000–200,000 base pairs, which defines the limit of resolution of FISH for identifying chromosomal changes. These DNA clones are labeled with fluorescent dyes and applied to metaphase spreads or interphase nuclei. The probe hybridizes to its homologous genomic sequence and thus labels a specific chromosomal region that can be visualized under a fluorescent microscope. The ability of FISH to circumvent the need for dividing cells is invaluable when a rapid diagnosis is warranted (e.g., when deciding to treat a patient with acute myeloid leukemia with retinoic acid, which is only effective in a particular subtype with a chromosomal translocation involving the retinoic acid receptor gene).

 

FISH can be performed on prenatal samples (e.g., cells obtained by amniocentesis, chorionic villus biopsy, or umbilical cord blood), peripheral blood lymphocytes, touch preparations from cancer biopsies, and even archival tissue sections. FISH has been used for detection of numeric abnormalities of chromosomes (aneuploidy); for the demonstration of subtle microdeletions or complex translocations not detectable by routine karyotyping; for analysis of gene amplification (e.g., HER2/NEU in breast cancer or N-MYC amplification in neuroblastomas); and for mapping newly isolated genes of interest to their chromosomal loci.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Conventional karyotyping: Although conventional karyotyping can detect chromosomal translocations, it is less sensitive and slower than FISH, particularly for small or complex translocations.

 

Option C. Bone marrow aspiration: This procedure is used to obtain a sample for analysis, but it is not a diagnostic test in itself for specific chromosomal translocations.

 

Option D. Next generation sequencing (NGS): NGS is a powerful tool for sequencing entire genomes, but it is not typically the first choice for detecting specific chromosomal translocations like t(11;22).

 

Educational Objective:

 

FISH is the preferred method for detecting the t(11;22) translocation, due to its ability to precisely identify specific chromosomal abnormalities in various sample types.

 

Ref: Robbin and Cotran pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 340-341​​​​​​

questions.text: What to be done next? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Bone biopsy

 

  • The given X-ray image shows a bone tumor which needs to be diagnosed.
  • The image shows a well-defined, lytic lesion (a darker area indicating bone destruction) in the distal femur, specifically in the medial femoral condyle. 
  • The lesion appears somewhat expansile and has a narrow zone of transition, suggesting a benign or low-grade aggressive lesion rather than a highly aggressive malignant tumor. 
  • There's no clear periosteal reaction or soft tissue mass immediately evident.
  • This appearance is highly suggestive of a Giant Cell Tumor (GCT), given its typical location (epiphyseal/metaphyseal region of long bones), lytic nature, and often eccentric appearance. 
  • Other possibilities might include an aneurysmal bone cyst or a chondroblastoma, but GCT is a strong consideration.
  • To reach the correct and final diagnosis, a bone biopsy test must be done. 
  • Bone biopsy is the most appropriate "next step" to definitively diagnose the nature of the lesion before proceeding with a potentially complex surgical intervention.
  • Without a biopsy, one cannot be absolutely certain of the benign or malignant nature, or the specific type of tumor.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Extended curettage with allograft. Curettage involves scraping out the tumor. "Extended" curettage aims to remove as much of the tumor as possible while preserving the bone. After removal, the resulting cavity often needs to be filled to maintain structural integrity. An allograft is one option for filling. This is a common treatment for GCTs, especially those that are not highly aggressive or are in a location where wide excision would lead to significant functional impairment. Extended curettage remains the preferred treatment option for Grade I and II GCT due to least postoperative morbidity, cost-effectiveness, and surgical convenience. The risk of recurrence is high after curettage alone,and therefore adjuvants such as cryosurgery, cement, phenol or a combination of these are recommended. 

 

Option C. Curettage. Curettage alone might be insufficient for a lesion like a GCT due to its tendency for local recurrence. Compared with resection, curettage is associated with a higher rate of local recurrence; however, curettage often allows for a better functional result. Curettage can be extended by the use of adjuvants, such as liquid nitrogen, phenol, polymethylmethacrylate (PMMA), or thermal cautery to extend destruction of tumor cells. Bone cavities have been reinforced with autologous bone grafts, allograft, PMMA bone cement, demineralized bone matrix and bone graft substitutes. These fillers augment final bone strength, reduce the risk of local recurrence (esp. giant cell tumors) and fill the empty cavities. 

 

Educational Objective:

  • To reach the correct and final diagnosis, a bone biopsy test must be done. 
  • The management will follow the result of the bone biopsy. 
  • If the question implies "what is the definitive treatment generally indicated for a lesion with this appearance (strongly suggesting GCT)," then options A or D would be relevant. Giant Cell Tumors are known for local recurrence after simple curettage, which is why extended curettage (with or without adjuvant therapy) is the preferred surgical treatment.

choices.text: Radical vulvectomy with unilateral LN dissection
Radical vulvectomy with bilateral LN dissection

questions.text: A 76-year-old female presented with a non-healing ulcer on the labia majora for a period of 6 months, measuring 2 cm x 3 cm. No lymph nodes were palpable. Biopsy shows squamous cell carcinoma. How do you manage this case? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Radical vulvectomy with bilateral LN dissection

 

Explanation:

 

This patient has a midline lesion on the labia majora, which indicates that the lesion is close to or crossing the midline. In cases of midline lesions or lesions within 2 cm of the midline, bilateral inguinofemoral lymph node dissection is necessary along with radical vulvectomy. This approach ensures that all potential pathways of lymphatic spread are adequately addressed.

 

New (2021) FIGO staging for carcinoma of the vulva:

 

  • Tumors 2 cm or less in size with 1 mm or less invasion: Treated by wide local excision.
  • Tumors more than 2 cm with more than 1 mm depth of invasion: Treated by modified radical vulvectomy with groin lymph node dissection.
  • LN dissection through separate incision: Lymph node dissection should be inguino-femoral.
  • Bilateral lymph node dissection: Performed for midline lesions and those within 2 cm of the midline.
  • Unilateral dissection: If the lesion is unilateral and ipsilateral nodes are negative, bilateral dissection is not necessary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radical vulvectomy with unilateral LN dissection: This would be appropriate for unilateral lesions with no evidence of contralateral spread, but not for midline lesions.

 

Option C. Simple vulvectomy: Simple vulvectomy is not sufficient for managing invasive squamous cell carcinoma with a lesion size of 2 cm x 3 cm and potential for deeper invasion.

 

Option D. Chemoradiation with resection: Chemoradiation followed by resection is typically reserved for advanced or inoperable cases, or where there is a need to downstage the tumor before surgery. This case can be managed surgically given the size and lack of palpable lymph nodes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For midline lesions or lesions within 2 cm of the midline in squamous cell carcinoma of the vulva, radical vulvectomy with bilateral inguinofemoral lymph node dissection is the appropriate management.

 

Ref: FIGO staging of CA vulva, Berek and Novak’s gynecology 15th edition pg 1436, William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition pg 484-485.

questions.text: A patient after a road traffic accident presents to the emergency room with difficulty in swallowing and slurred speech. Investigations reveal fractures in the occipitotemporal region. Which of the following areas should be tested in order to find the nerve which is involved? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 2

 

Explanation:

 

The occipitotemporal fracture in the clinical scenario is suggestive of involvement of the 9th and 10th cranial nerves, which are tested by pressing on the uvula, which is indicated as 2 in the image.

 

The jugular foramen is located between the lower border of the petrous part of the temporal bone and the condylar part of the occipital bone. As the investigations reveal fractures in the occipitotemporal region, along with the history of difficulty in swallowing and slurred speech, are suggestive of injury to the glossopharyngeal and vagus nerve passing through the jugular foramen.

 

Unilateral lesions of IX and X cranial nerves are commonly caused by skull-base fractures, strokes, or tumors.

 

Glossopharyngeal and Vagus nerve examination include:

 

  • Observing the position and symmetry of the palate and uvula(marked as 2 in the given image) at rest and with phonation ("aah").
  • The pharyngeal (gag") reflex is evaluated by stimulating the posterior pharyngeal wall on each side with a sterile, blunt object (e.g., tongue blade)

 

Individuals who have a proximal unilateral vagus nerve lesion report having trouble swallowing. On the affected side, the soft palate muscles will be weak. When the patient is asked to utter "aah," for example, an attempt to elevate the soft palate voluntarily will demonstrate a deficit in that side's ability to do so. Due to the palatal muscles' unopposed action on that side, there will also be a deviation of the uvula to the typical side along with this.

 

Other Options:

 

Option. A. 1: This area does not relate to the glossopharyngeal or vagus nerves, which are crucial in the described symptoms.

 

Option. C. 3: This area is likely distant from the jugular foramen where nerves IX and X pass, thus not directly involved with the symptoms presented.

 

Option. D. 4: This lower section of the brain and skull does not typically involve the pathways or exit points of the cranial nerves implicated in swallowing and speech functions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of occipitotemporal fractures with symptoms of difficulty in swallowing and slurred speech, it is critical to assess the function of the glossopharyngeal and vagus nerves, as these are commonly affected by such injuries. Testing should focus on the functionality of the palate and uvula where these nerves can be clinically evaluated.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old male presents to your clinic after a dog bite earlier in the day. Physical examination reveals a 1.5 cm abrasion with some oozing. Given the nature of the wound and the potential interventions post-exposure, which combination of actions and descriptors best characterizes the appropriate management? [INICET NOV 2022]

 

  1. Category 3 wound
  2. Wash the wound with normal tap water for 15-20 minutes
  3. Clean the wound with spirit
  4. Loose suturing of the wound with a proper dressing
  5. Equine immunoglobin is given at a dose of 40 IU/kg of body weight, twice
  6. Intra-dermal vaccine is administered on days 0, 3, 7, 28
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) 1, 2, 3, 6

 

The patient with a dog bite presented with an abrasion, which comes under category 3 wound.

 

The components of post–exposure prophylaxis are:

 

  1. Local treatment of wound
  2. Antibiotics and anti-tetanus measures
  3. Active immunization against rabies – if indicated
  4. Passive immunization with rabies immunoglobulin – if indicated
  5. Observe the animal for 10 days from the day of bite:
    • If healthy after 10 days: Discontinue post – exposure vaccination
    • If dies within observation period: complete PEP
    • If observation not possible: complete the post – exposure vaccination

 

Other Option: 

 

Statement 4 – Abrasion wound doesn’t require suturing

 

Statement 5 – Equine Rabies Ig at dose of 40 IU/kg should be given only once.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following is not a dimorphic fungus? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pneumocystis jirovecii

 

Pneumocystis jirovecii is not a dimorphic fungus, it is a yeast like organism that causes Pneumocystis pneumonia, particularly in immunocompromised individuals, such as those with HIV/AIDS.

 

Dimorphic fungi:

 

  • Dimorphic fungi are fungi that can exist in two different forms depending on the temperature.
  • At 25°C (room temperature), they grow in a mold (mycelial) form.
  • At 37°C (body temperature), they grow in a yeast form.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blastomyces dermatitidis: A dimorphic fungus causing blastomycosis.

 

Option B. Histoplasma capsulatum: A dimorphic fungus causing histoplasmosis.

 

Option D. Penicillium marneffei: A dimorphic fungus causing penicilliosis.

 

Educational Objective

 

Pneumocystis jirovecii is not a dimorphic fungus

 

Dimorphic fungi:

 

  • Blastomyces dermatitidis
  • Histoplasma capsulatum
  • Paracoccidioides brasiliensis
  • Penicillium marneffei
  • Sporothrix schenckii
  • Coccidioides immitis
  • Coccidioides posadasii

questions.text: Which of the following staphylococcal infections is not toxin mediated? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Septicemia

 

Staphylococcal septicemia is not toxin mediated. It occurs due to the invasion of bacterial organisms into the bloodstream causing an inflammatory response to bacterial products, leading to various manifestations seen in sepsis.

 

Toxin mediated staphylococcal infections are:

 

  • Food poisoning - caused by enterotoxin
  • Toxic shock syndrome- caused by toxic shock syndrome toxin
  • Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome- caused by exfoliative/epidermolytic toxin

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Food poisoning: Caused by the ingestion of preformed enterotoxins in contaminated food.

 

Option B. Toxic shock syndrome: Caused by the release of TSST-1 and other superantigens leading to severe systemic symptoms.

 

Option D. Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome: Caused by exfoliative toxins leading to the destruction of the skin's epidermal layer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Staphylococcal septicemia is not mediated by toxins, unlike staphylococcal food poisoning, toxic shock syndrome, and staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome, which are all toxin-mediated infections.

choices.text: Blast of air

questions.text: A man who was involved in a bomb blast at a railway station was brought to the hospital with multiple small puncture wounds to the left side of the chest and multiple small abrasions all over the body. Which of the following mechanisms is responsible for these injuries? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Flying missiles

 

The case scenarios define multiple abrasions and puncture wounds suggestive of blast injuries due to flying missiles.

 

T.K. Marshall's (Marshall's triad of bomb injuries) :

 

    • Abrasions
    • Bruises/contusions
    • Puncture lacerations

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Blast of air: Primarily causes primary blast injuries, which affect air-filled organs and do not typically result in puncture wounds.

 

Option C. Explosion burns: Involve thermal injuries and burns rather than puncture wounds and abrasions.

 

Option D. Furniture abrasions: Would result from the victim being thrown into furniture or debris, causing blunt force injuries rather than puncture wounds.

 

Educational Objective

 

Classification of Blast injuries:

 

Injuries from explosions are traditionally classified into:

 

  1. Primary blast injuries: injuries due to solely to the blast wave
  2. Secondary blast or explosive injury: primarily ballistic trauma resulting from fragmentation wounds from the explosive device or the environment
  3. Tertiary blast or explosive injury: result of displacement of the victim or environmental structures, is largely blunt traumatic injuries
  4. Quaternary explosive injuries: burns, toxins, and radiologic contamination

questions.text: Identify the foramen marked in the image below: (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Foramen rotundum

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows the sphenoid bone. The foramen marked is the foramen rotundum. Maxillary branch of trigeminal nerve passes through it.

 

 

The foramen rotundum is a small circular opening in the greater wing of the sphenoid bone, located in the middle cranial fossa of the skull. It serves as a passage for the maxillary nerve (CN V2), which is one of the three branches of the trigeminal nerve.

 

The maxillary nerve exits the cranial cavity through the foramen rotundum and then travels through the pterygopalatine fossa, where it gives off several branches that innervate the maxillary teeth, the maxillary sinus, and the skin of the face in the maxillary region.

 

Other structures that may pass through the foramen rotundum include small blood vessels and veins, but these are less significant than the maxillary nerve in terms of clinical relevance.

 

Other Options :

 

Option B. Foramen Ovale:

 

  • Location: The foramen ovale is also located in the sphenoid bone, adjacent (Postero- lateral) to the foramen rotundum.
  • Contents: It transmits the mandibular nerve (another branch of the trigeminal nerve or CN V3), the accessory meningeal artery, and sometimes a small emissary vein.

 

Option C. Vidian Canal (Pterygoid Canal):

 

  • Location: The vidian canal is a small canal in the sphenoid bone, extending from the pterygopalatine fossa to the middle cranial fossa.
  • Contents: It contains the vidian nerve, which is a branch of the maxillary nerve (CN V2), as well as the vidian artery and sympathetic fibers.

 

Option D. Foramen Spinosum:

 

  • Location: The foramen spinosum is situated in the greater wing of the sphenoid bone. It is present postero-lateral to foramen ovale
  • Contents: It transmits the middle meningeal artery, a branch of the maxillary artery, and the middle meningeal vein.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 60 years old male patient was undergoing laparoscopic cholecystectomy. During the surgery, it was observed that there was a sudden decrease in etCO2  to 8 mm Hg, SpO2 was 90%, BP dropped to 80/50 mm Hg and peak airway pressure was observed to be 18 mm Hg. Which of the most probable diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. CO2 embolism

 

Explanation:

 

In the scenario described, a sudden decrease in end-tidal CO2 (etCO2) to 8 mm Hg, along with a drop in blood pressure (BP) to 80/50 mm Hg and oxygen saturation (SpO2) to 90%, but with normal peak airway pressure (18 mm Hg), strongly suggests a CO2 embolism. During laparoscopic procedures, CO2 is used for insufflation to create a pneumoperitoneum, which can occasionally enter a blood vessel and cause a CO2 embolism. This event leads to a rapid decrease in etCO2 due to reduced return of CO2 to the lungs, hypoxemia, and cardiovascular collapse. The normal peak airway pressures help differentiate it from other causes of acute respiratory distress.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pneumothorax: A pneumothorax, or collapsed lung, could occur due to barotrauma from mechanical ventilation or surgical complications. However, it typically causes an increase in peak airway pressures due to increased resistance to ventilation. The absence of increased peak airway pressures makes pneumothorax less likely in this case.

 

Option C. Endobronchial Intubation: Endobronchial intubation occurs when the endotracheal tube is inserted too far and intubates one of the main bronchi, typically the right main bronchus. This can lead to hypoventilation of one lung, causing a decrease in etCO2 and SpO2. However, peak airway pressures might be higher due to one-lung ventilation, which was not observed here.

 

Option D. Bronchospasm: Bronchospasm involves the constriction of the muscles in the walls of the bronchioles, leading to narrowed airways. This would usually present with an increase in peak airway pressures due to the narrowed airways, which is not consistent with the normal peak airway pressures reported in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During laparoscopic surgery, the sudden onset of hypotension, hypoxemia, and a significant decrease in etCO2 with normal peak airway pressures suggests a CO2 embolism, a rare but potentially life-threatening complication.

questions.text: What is the reason behind Senile Atrophy? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Reduced blood supply

 

Senile atrophy is seen when there is a reduced blood supply to a tissue.

 

  • Atrophy is decrease in cell size and/or number due to decreased demand or functional loss.
  • 2 pathways responsible for it: Ubiquitin Pathway (via Proteasomes) and Autophagy (Defense mechanism).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Denervation: Atrophy due to loss of nerve supply is known as denervation atrophy, commonly seen in conditions like poliomyelitis.

 

Option B. Decreased nutrition: This refers to atrophy due to inadequate nutrient supply, leading to cachexia.

 

Option C. Decreased workload: This refers to disuse atrophy, where tissues reduce in size due to inactivity, such as muscle wasting in immobilized limbs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Senile atrophy is primarily due to reduced blood supply, leading to tissue shrinkage and loss of function with aging.

questions.text: A 50-year-old chronic smoker presented with mild recurrent hemoptysis without fever or weight loss. The chest X-ray appears normal and the sputum is negative for AFB. Which of the following is the most useful diagnostic investigation? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CT Thorax

 

CECT is preferred when suspicion of malignancy is high. HRCT is preferred to look at lung parenchyma/suspected ILD.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MRI is used to assess for metastasis, secondary changes. MRI is NOT preferred over CT scan for evaluation of distant metastasis and invasion.

 

Option B. Bronchoscopy is used for biopsy of mass based on accessibility. More central masses are amenable to bronchoscopic biopsy. Peripheral masses are sampled by CT-guided biopsy.

 

Option D. Bronchography is no longer used in today’s practice.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The choice of CT Thorax (HRCT or CECT) is critical for early detection of potential malignancies or other significant lung conditions in a high-risk individual, particularly when initial less sensitive tests like chest X-ray and sputum analysis have failed to elucidate the cause of symptoms.

 

Reference - (Harrison 21E, 597,598) Resp Med/Hemoptysis/Lung CA

questions.text: A young male presented with palpitations and hence ECG was taken. ECG demonstrated narrow complex tachycardia and his BP was 70/40 mm of Hg. What is the next step in the management of this patient?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Synchronized DC Cardioversion

 

In the case of a patient presenting with palpitations, narrow complex tachycardia, and hypotension (BP 70/40 mm Hg), the patient is considered hemodynamically unstable. The appropriate management for an unstable patient with a pulse is synchronized DC cardioversion. This intervention is critical to restore normal rhythm promptly and prevent deterioration.

 

Synchronized cardioversion delivers a shock that is timed with the QRS complex, preventing the shock from falling on the T wave, which could induce ventricular fibrillation. This is the standard treatment for unstable supraventricular tachycardia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. IV Adenosine (6mg): IV Adenosine is used for the treatment of stable narrow complex tachycardia. It is not appropriate for an unstable patient due to its transient effect and the need for rapid intervention in unstable conditions.

 

Option C. Carotid Sinus Massage: Carotid sinus massage is a vagal maneuver used to manage stable narrow complex tachycardia. It is not recommended for unstable patients because it may not be effective quickly enough to stabilize the patient.

 

Option D. IV Amiodarone: IV Amiodarone is typically used for stable wide complex tachycardia, especially monomorphic ventricular tachycardia. It is not the first-line treatment for unstable narrow complex tachycardia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In hemodynamically unstable patients with narrow complex tachycardia, synchronized DC cardioversion is the immediate treatment of choice.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a known history of diabetes mellitus presents with a BP of 150/90 and dizziness. What is the best way to manage this patient? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Diet, Exercise, Lifestyle modification + Amlodipine

 

For a 60-year-old patient with diabetes and hypertension (BP 150/90 mmHg), it is critical to start pharmacological therapy along with lifestyle modifications to reduce cardiovascular risk. Current guidelines, including the 2023 European Society of Cardiology (ESC) guidelines, recommend initiating antihypertensive therapy in such patients due to the high risk of cardiovascular events. Amlodipine, a calcium channel blocker, is an appropriate choice for initial antihypertensive therapy in diabetic patients. It effectively lowers blood pressure and is well-tolerated, without negatively impacting glycemic control. Ideally, an ACE inhibitor or ARB would be preferred, but if not available, a calcium channel blocker like amlodipine is a suitable alternative.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diet, Exercise, Lifestyle modification + Metoprolol: Metoprolol, a beta-blocker, is not first-line therapy for hypertension unless there is a specific indication such as coronary artery disease, heart failure, or angina. Beta-blockers are not the preferred initial treatment for hypertensive diabetics.

 

Option B. Diet, Exercise, Lifestyle modification: While lifestyle modifications are important, they are insufficient alone for managing hypertension in a diabetic patient, who is at high cardiovascular risk.

 

Option C. Diet + Prazosin: Prazosin, an alpha-blocker, is not typically used as first-line therapy for hypertension. It may be used in patients with benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) but offers no additional advantage in this context and may cause orthostatic hypotension, worsening dizziness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For hypertensive diabetic patients, it is essential to start pharmacological therapy along with lifestyle modifications to reduce cardiovascular risk. Amlodipine is an appropriate choice for initial therapy in this context.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient with a history of prior neck radiation for lymphoma is diagnosed with 2 x 3 cm papillary thyroid cancer. No lymph node enlargement is present. What is the treatment? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Total thyroidectomy

 

Explanation: 

 

Total thyroidectomy is now the preferred approach only for those differentiated thyroid cancers (DTCs) at higher risk for recurrence:

  • Tumor at least  4 cm 
  • Gross extrathyroidal extension 
  • Evidence of metastatic disease 
  • Radiation-induced DTC (mentioned in the history) 
  • Familial non-medullary thyroid cancer 
  • Multifocal bilateral DTC.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemithyroidectomy:

 

  • History of radiation is a high-risk feature requiring total thyroidectomy
  • Hemithyroidectomy is reserved for low-risk, small unifocal tumors without risk factors

 

Option C. Hemithyroidectomy + MRND:

 

  • MRND is not indicated without clinical lymphadenopathy
  • MRND is mainly done for medullary thyroid cancer
  • Hemithyroidectomy is inadequate given the radiation history

 

Option D. Total Thyroidectomy + MRND:

 

  • No lymph node involvement noted
  • For papillary thyroid cancer without lymphadenopathy, central compartment (level VI) clearance may be done, but not MRND

 

Educational Objective: 

 

History of radiation exposure is an absolute indication for total thyroidectomy in differentiated thyroid cancer, regardless of tumor size.

questions.text: Which of the following structures of brachial plexus do not give branches? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Divisions

 

Explanation:

 

The divisions in the brachial plexus do not give any branches.

 

However, the roots, trunks, and cords of the brachial plexus give out direct branches.

 

The brachial plexus is a complex network of nerves that originates from the ventral rami of the fifth cervical to the first thoracic spinal nerves (C5-T1). The brachial plexus is typically organized into five stages: roots, trunks, divisions, cords, and terminal branches.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Roots: The roots of the brachial plexus are the five ventral rami (C5-T1) that serve as the origin of the brachial plexus. These roots give off several branches:

 

  • C5 root can contribute to the dorsal scapular nerve.
  • C5 and C6 roots together give rise to the upper trunk, but before they merge, they can give off the nerve to the subclavius muscle (from C5 and C6).
  • C8 and T1 roots can contribute to the long thoracic nerve along with C7 root.

 

Option B. Cords: The cords are named based on their position relative to the axillary artery: lateral, medial, and posterior cords.

 

  • The lateral cord gives branches like the lateral pectoral nerve.
  • The medial cord gives branches like the medial pectoral, medial cutaneous nerve of arm, and medial cutaneous nerve of forearm.
  • The posterior cord provides branches like the upper subscapular, thoracodorsal, and lower subscapular nerves.

 

Option C. Trunks: There are three trunks in the brachial plexus: upper, middle, and lower.

 

  • The upper trunk is formed by the union of C5 and C6 roots and gives off the suprascapular nerve and the nerve to the omohyoid muscle.
  • The middle and lower trunks usually do not give any significant branches.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Each trunk divides into two divisions: an anterior division and a posterior division. The divisions do not provide any branches.

choices.text: Placenta membranacea
Placenta succenturiata
Circumvallate placenta

questions.text: A pregnant woman delivered a baby with the normal expulsion of an intact placenta. After half an hour she started bleeding per vaginal. On examination, she was hypotensive, and a boggy mass was palpated per abdomen. Ultrasound showed retained placental tissues. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Placenta succenturiate

 

  • It is mentioned here that the placenta expelled looked normal and intact
  • In such a case, if there is a retained component, it could be a succenturiate lobe
  • Placenta succenturiata refers to a placenta with an additional lobe/lobes of placental tissue located a few centimeters away.
  • The ancillary lobes can be associated with complications such as placenta previa, vasa previa, postpartum hemorrhage or infection.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Placenta membranacea:

 

  • Placenta membranacea is a rare placental disorder characterized by the presence of fetal membranes (complete or partially) covered by chorionic villi.
  • Associated with painless vaginal bleeding in the second and third trimester
  • This condition can be associated with other placental abnormalities, such as placenta previa or accreta.
  • Perinatal outcome may include stillbirth, preterm delivery, or neonatal death.

 

 

Option C. Circummarginate placenta:

 

  • Uncommon variation in placental morphology in which a thin fibrous ring is present at the margin of the chorionic plate where the fetal vessels appear to terminate.
  • The placenta is unduly large and thin. The placenta not only develops from the chorion frondosum but also from the chorion laeve so that the whole of the ovum is practically covered by the placenta
  • Associated with Abortion, Hydrorrhea gravidarum (excessive watery vaginal discharge), Antepartum hemorrhage, Growth retardation of the baby, Preterm delivery and Retained placenta or membranes.

 

 

Option D. Circumvallate placenta:

 

  • The fetal surface is divided into a central depressed zone surrounded by a thickened white ring which is usually complete.
  • The ring is situated at varying distances from the margin of the placenta. The ring is composed of a double fold of amnion and chorion with degenerated decidua (vera) and fibrin in between
  • Vessels radiate from the cord insertion as far as the ring and then disappear from view
  • The peripheral zone outside the ring is thicker and the edge is elevated and rounded.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Placenta succenturiata is characterized by an additional lobe of placental tissue separate from the main placenta, which can be retained postpartum, leading to hemorrhage and requiring careful monitoring and management.

 

Ref: Page 253, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

choices.text: It undergoes spontaneous resolution after cold decreases
It shows Ad type of curve

questions.text: A patient has otitis media with effusion. Which of the following is wrong?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It shows Ad type of curve

 

Otitis media with effusion (OME) is a condition characterized by the presence of fluid in the middle ear without signs or symptoms of acute ear infection. The incorrect statement regarding it is, It shows Ad type of curve. This statement is incorrect. OME typically shows a B type of tympanogram curve. A B type curve indicates the presence of middle ear fluid. An Ad type curve is associated with ossicular discontinuity, which is not related to OME.

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is bilateral: Can be true but not mandatory; OME can be unilateral or bilateral.

 

Option B. It undergoes spontaneous resolution after cold decreases: True, as the condition often resolves with the resolution of the underlying URTI.

 

Option C. It is associated with cold: True, as URTI and colds can lead to Eustachian tube dysfunction and subsequent fluid accumulation in the middle ear.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Otitis media with effusion shows a B type of tympanogram curve, not an Ad type curve.

questions.text: A TPN bag consists of 100g glucose, 30g amino acids, and 40g lipids. What is the amount of calories delivered? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 880 Kcal

 

In patients who cannot (unconscious; removal of large part of gut) or should not (major trauma or surgery) use their gastrointestinal tract, total parenteral feeding has to be resorted. The solution may be infused through one of the large vessels like subclavian vein or superior vena cava, where the blood flow is sufficient to dilute the hypertonic solution. This procedure is known as total parenteral nutrition (TPN) or intravenous hyperalimentation.

 

The number of calories delivered by the given TPN (Total Parenteral Nutrition) bag is 880 Kcal.

 

The caloric values of different food components are:

• Carbohydrate (glucose) - 4KCal/g

• Proteins (amino acids) - 4.2KCal/g = ~4KCal/g

• Fat (lipids) - 9Kcal/g

 

Calculation of the number of calories:

• 100 gm of glucose = 100 × 4 KCal=400 KCal

• 30 gm of amino acids = 30 × 4 KCal= 120 KCal

• 40 gm of lipids = 40 × 9 KCal= 360 KCal

Total amount of calories delivered= 400+120+360=880 Kcal

 

Note: The caloric value of alcohol is 7KCal/g.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Total Parenteral Nutrition (TPN) is a method used to deliver nutrients directly into the bloodstream when patients cannot use their gastrointestinal tract. The caloric value of the nutrients provided in the TPN bag can be calculated based on the caloric content of carbohydrates, proteins, and fats.

 

Caloric Values:

 

  • Carbohydrates (glucose): 4 KCal/g
  • Proteins (amino acids): Approximately 4 KCal/g
  • Fats (lipids): 9 KCal/g

choices.text: To improve quality of life patient
Nothing is done in palliative care

questions.text: A 68-year-old male with a history of stage IV non-small cell lung cancer presents with worsening dyspnea, non-productive cough, and uncontrolled pain despite current medication. He has declined further aggressive treatment. What stands true for Palliative care? [INICET NOV 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) To improve quality of life patient

 

Explanation:

 

  • Palliative care is a specialized medical care focused on providing relief from the symptoms and stress of a serious illness.
  • The primary goal of palliative care is to improve the quality of life for the patient. 
  • It involves treating pain and other distressing symptoms, providing psychological and spiritual care, and supporting the patient and their family to cope with the challenges of a serious illness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. To cure disease: This is incorrect. Palliative care does not aim to cure the underlying disease but focuses on alleviating symptoms and improving the quality of life for both the patient and their family.

 

Option B. Do nothing to prolong life: Palliative care does not necessarily aim to prolong life, nor does it hasten death. It’s about enhancing the quality of life and may also indirectly prolong it by improving general health and well-being.

 

Option D. Nothing is done in palliative care: This is incorrect. Palliative care involves active and comprehensive management of various issues that arise with serious illnesses, including physical, emotional, social, and spiritual aspects of care.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Palliative care is crucial for improving the quality of life for patients with serious illnesses. 
  • It addresses a wide range of needs, ensuring the patient’s comfort and supporting the family through difficult times, emphasizing symptom management and personal support over curative treatments.

choices.text: Zidovudine is used as monotherapy for post-exposure prophylaxis
Washing hands with soap and water is advised
Baseline viral markers of health care personnel should be done at the time of prick
Follow up viral markers of health care personnel should be measured at 6 weeks

questions.text: A nurse got accidental prick from the HIV infected needle. Which of the following statements is false regarding the management of this nurse? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Zidovudine is used as monotherapy for post-exposure prophylaxis

 

Post-Exposure Prophylaxis (PEP) involves a series of steps to reduce the risk of HIV infection after potential exposure, such as a needlestick injury.

 

  1. Washing the Wound: Immediately after exposure, the wound should be washed thoroughly with soap and water. This helps to reduce the risk of infection.
  2. Baseline Viral Markers: Blood samples should be taken from the exposed individual to measure baseline viral markers. This provides a reference point to determine if the infection was acquired.
  3. Triple Drug Therapy: PEP should be initiated within 72 hours of exposure, preferably as soon as possible. The recommended regimen includes a combination of three antiretroviral drugs:
    • Tenofovir
    • Lamivudine (or Emtricitabine)
    • A boosted protease inhibitor (such as lopinavir/ritonavir)

 

Zidovudine monotherapy is not recommended. Combination therapy is more effective in preventing seroconversion.

 

  1. Follow-Up Testing: Follow-up viral markers should be measured at 6 weeks post-exposure to check for HIV infection. Additional testing may also be done at 3 months and 6 months.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Washing hands with soap and water is advised: This is correct. Washing the wound with soap and water immediately after exposure is a crucial first step.

 

Option C. Baseline viral markers of health care personnel should be done at the time of prick: This is correct. Establishing baseline viral markers at the time of exposure is essential for monitoring potential seroconversion.

 

Option D. Follow up viral markers of health care personnel should be measured at 6 weeks: This is correct. Follow-up testing at 6 weeks is recommended to detect any early seroconversion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

POST EXPOSURE PROPHYLAXIS

 

  • Treatment should be started within 72 hours of exposure, preferably as early as possible
  • At first the wound is washed with soap and water.
  • Secondly before initiating drug therapy blood samples are taken to measure the baseline viral markers
  • Then, triple drug therapy is given which includes Tenofovir, Lamivudine and a boosted protease inhibitor for 28 days.
  • After 6 weeks again viral markers are measured to check for the infection.

 

Reference: KDT 8th/872

The assertion is independently a false statement, but the reasons is independently a true statement.
Both assertion and reason are true statements
Both assertion and reason are false statements

questions.text:
Assertion: Resting membrane potential is dependent on proteins and phosphate ions.

 

Reason: Diffusion potential can be calculated using Nernst Equation. (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Both assertion and reason are true statements

 

Resting membrane potential refers to the electrical charge difference across the cell membrane of a neuron or other excitable cells when the cell is at rest, meaning it is not actively transmitting signals. This potential is maintained by the uneven distribution of ions, primarily sodium (Na+), potassium (K+), chloride (Cl-), and other negative ions, across the cell membrane.

 

Nernst equation is used to calculate the diffusion potential (also known as the equilibrium potential) for a specific ion across a semi-permeable membrane.

 

 

Where:

 

  • E is the equilibrium potential for the ion.
  • R is the ideal gas constant.
  • T is the absolute temperature (in Kelvin).
  • z is the valence (charge) of the ion.
  • F is Faraday's constant.
  • [Cout]​ and [Cin]​ are the concentrations of the ion outside and inside the membrane, respectively.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Resting membrane potential is maintained by the uneven distribution of ions, primarily sodium (Na+), potassium (K+), chloride (Cl-), and other negative ions (including proteins and phosphate ions), across the cell membrane.
  • The Nernst equation is used to calculate the diffusion potential (also known as the equilibrium potential) for a specific ion across a semi-permeable membrane.
